110131208.review:
I'm recommending Royal Court because I believe that this concept is 'unique' and adds more levels of fun to the game. However it's important to point out that for the current price you're not getting much. 

First let's start with the positives, the special part about Royal Court is the 3D modelling. The new events that can occur from within your throne room are fun to play through and helps make the game last a bit longer by creating more things to do. Furthermore Royal Court introduces changes to the culture system best described as more dynamic now. Following that is the reintroduction of artifacts and different court positions. So there's a good amount of features within this DLC.

But on the contrary to this, Royal Court can be a bit lacking in areas. As a player you get to decide how much money you'd like to spend on your court and sadly it doesn't feel like your financial decisions carry much weight as you alternate your spending. Additionally there isn't much you can do inside your throne room besides tending to random events and holding court, even then there isn't much that visually happens within these events either. It doesn't feel as if they're utilizing the full potential of what they created which is a shame.

However these are baby steps into new territory. Hopefully Paradox keeps the momentum going and does something impressive with how you handle your court in the future. Until then we can only wait and see

Overall if you like playing CK3 and want to purchase DLC for it, you're better off waiting for Royal Court to go on sale first. If I could pick between 1-10 for this game it'd be a 6.5, the features itself are very nice in concept but in practice needs more polishing. Let's hope the polishing are free updates and not something you have to buy.

110129679.review:
My relatively brief thoughts on each of the new systems:

3D Court Room: So from the start I had a bad feeling about this when they said they wanted to go with a 3D court room, because in my opinion that makes no sense. Paradox makes map games, and map games are what we love from Paradox, they are incredibly unique in that way and there are few other developers we'd consider make "grand strategy games". Them trying to create a more RP friendly experience is well and good but I don't think that idea should ever take backseat to actual gameplay and mechanics. The immersion you get from the court is... okay, I guess. It's not something I'm ever excited about, and personally feel looks extremely bland, adding very little to the overall experience.

Culture System: This was what I felt was the true meat and potatoes of the expansion, and a revamped culture system is what I've been wanting for a very long time. However does it really add up to the original hype? Not really. The new systems are nice and definitely will make each playthrough more interesting and more diverse, but ultimately it's a very slow-paced system that you can't utilize all too well until mid-late game when you can accumulate a lot of prestige or decide to make random hybrids just to steal peoples innovations (something I don't care to do because it doesn't make sense from an in-game narrative standpoint, and Paradox is really trying to push roleplay so this doesn't make sense). It's great if you're playing a viking though. I think I'm starting to see a trend with Paradox, hmm.

Language: What in gods unholy name is this? I don't know if I'm just an idiot who can't figure out the most basic thing but this feels not only completely useless mechanically, but also functionless. Learning other languages doesn't seem to actually do anything productive other than add a slight RP flair, which I don't care for. The idea seems nice but I feel like even if it does have some function that I'm not properly making use of, it's still worthless and adds nothing.

Artifacts: Aight here is the big money. I honestly don't have any real complaints about this, I think they did a pretty solid job on it and it's just CK2's system but infinitely better since it works with the court room. You feel like the things you create and collect actually matter in a way, and sure you can probably break the game with some insanely OP items but honestly that is probably part of the fun, just like in CK2.

Minor Titles: I like this quite a lot. At the end of the day it feels almost as pointless as they were in CK2 but they are in fact, not useless. So that is nice. The buffs you get from most of them aren't really noticeable most of the time, but when you start bringing in the cash it adds some more flavor to your playthrough since they can do some neat stuff. During one of my playthroughs I had my trash diplo viking leading armies and he didn't get hurt once, most likely because my bodyguards were actually doing their job. Perhaps I got lucky, but I like to think the feature was doing its job.

Is It Worth It?: I'm probably forgetting some big things but honestly cba about thinking about it. Overall it may seem like my attitude is quite negative towards the DLC but I enjoy it quite a bit, and it will a lot of fun to each of my playthroughs going forward, and since this is one of my favorite games with about 1000 hours into now, it's worth it for me. So for me it's a no brainer, however this is 1000% overpriced. The amount of content it brings to the table feels on par with Northern Lords in size, but obviously more ambitious. If you are having conflicting thoughts about wanting to get it then you should probably wait for a sale, but if you plan on playing a lot like I do, then it's worth it. It's a shame we waited over a year for just this, but I'm hoping this is just the foundation for bigger plans that Paradox has for CK3s future. I understand that the pandemic slowed things down drastically, and we were supposed to get this ages ago so I don't hold that against Paradox, and always am hoping for the best. 

I do hope the DLC pans out well because it would crush me if they canned CK3 like they did with Imperator and many more projects they had in the works. I know it's been a very difficult year for them financially, and part of me is worried this isn't going to help all too much.

MAIS

This honestly is a terrible DLC even if you view it through Paradox's rose tinted glasses, for all the extra "3D" shit they wanted to add and show off, if you upgrade your court fashion you can't see the difference, there is no discernible difference between your court after upgrading it and paying the extra gold upkeep cost for it which is near never worth it. All the events are still basically just pop ups, just inside 3D courtroom space, the event where someone becomes your footstool? Your ruler will not have a footstool within the 3D courtroom. the only thing you can add to your courtroom is artifacts which give measly bonuses and you never spend gold on because it isn't worth it, they just stack up over the course of conquering AI. Also one big glaring problem is that if you are tribal or not at least a king in rank, you don't get a court, so easily over 50% of the starting game just doesn't have a 3D court at all... 

The cultural aspect of the game is interesting but at the same time, there seem to be arbitrary caveats as to when you can reform or divulge, like "Your culture is not at least 100 years old", why does that matter if I want to start a different culture?  On top of this there are huge hurdles for what seem again like seemingly small buffs for such a vast amount of effort focusing on it.

In conclusion, its terrible, the fact I waited so long for this and sat through 30 minutes of Paradox's stupid Twitch stream for it to drop makes me want to go back in time and smack myself. This could've and probably should be base game content, it doesn't honestly seem like they did much for how long it took and how much they acted like they added.

110103250.review:
The culture mechanics are interesting, but the court gimmick is half-baked at best. This DLC is way too expensive for what it offers ($30 for less actual content than most CK2 DLCs, which are half that price). If you're really gonna buy it, do so on sale, because otherwise you're getting ripped off.
The fact that the devs spent this much dev time on a DLC that ultimately does very little is worrying, when they probably could have pumped out multiple flavor packs to help make different parts of the map actually feel, you know, [i] different [/i] in the amount of time it took between Northern Lords and Royal Court. You can tell that most of it was spent on the Court itself, which is ultimately just a vehicle for flavor events that could have worked the same as the pre-existing events without needing a fancy 3D model gimmick. While the Court could be improved over time, I don't think it'd be worth the effort of fixing this lackluster Sims Medieval wannabe mechanic.

110102334.review:
Toto DLC přidává pár věcí, které dále rozepíšu. 
1. DESIGNER pro dynastický erb a znak země je hezká a pro mě velice vítaná věc. 
2. ÚPRAVY A VYTVÁŘENÍ KULTUR jsou zábavné a zajímavé ale chtělo by to aby se vývojáři trochu více zaměřili na jazyky, které jsou v současnosti absolutně zbytečné. 
3. ARTEFAKTY jsou hezká blbůstka se kterou se dá vyplnit dost nudy v pozdějších částech hry. Jediným problémem je množství, které budete vlastnit po pár hodinách hraní.
4. POZICE U DVORA jsou spíš otravné a nezajímavé, protože kromě dvou nebo tří pozic jsou téměř všechny k ničemu, stojí hromadu peněz a i když je nemáte vůbec o nic nepřicházíte nijak to gameplay neovlivňuje. 
5. Jako poslední je zde váš vlastní DVŮR, ve kterém si můžete vystavit své artefakty a odehrávají se tady eventy s vašimi poddanými, sousedy, rodinou a poskoky od dvora. Zní to hezky ale eventů uvidíte za celou hru maximálně 15 z nějakých 36, pokud nesplníte všechny požadavky, zkrátka jsou všechny na stejné brdo a navíc většina má negativní následky a nebo přicházíte o peníze. Vzhled vašeho dvora ovlivníte pouze tím kde se nachází a pravé vystavenými artefakty nic víc, je jedno jestli máte nejúžasnější dvůr na světě protože soused vedle vás bude mít dvůr úplně stejný i kdyby ho měl nejhorší. Animací je zde opravdu málo nejsem nějaký vývojář ale myslím si že za takovou cenu by hlavní část celého dodatku měla být opravdu propracovaná což není.
Cena je obrovská, mám hromadu celých her a ne dodatků za stejnou nebo i menší cenu. Odůvodnéní COVIDem a časem mi přijde hloupé a pokud Paradox ještě dál nerozšíří obsah, který zde zatím je, díky nějaké aktualizaci, tak své kladné hodnocení budu nucený změnit.

110100954.review:
I feel like Paradox put a ton of time and resources into this DLC - but to so little effect! What the game needed was some new, solid, FUN mechanics and regional flavour; CK2's Holy Fury should be the mark towards which every CK3 expansion should aim. Unfortunately, what it got in this DLC was a pretty, but otherwise boring and irritating, extra menu, i.e. the royal court itself. It's heart-breaking, because it looks like it's taken the developers forever to make, but it makes the game less, and not more, enjoyable.

Credit where credit's due; the culture overhaul is exactly what the game needed. (I wonder what might have happened if Paradox had spent more time on that sort of thing, rather than pretty gimmicks?) But I'm told that that's part of the free update.

110089977.review:
Lots of reviews out there.  Many of the negative reviews are based on price vs content.  They feel for 10-15 it would be a good buy but 30 is a no go.  I do not really judge if something is good or bad based on pricing.  Sure it can and should be a contributing factor in deciding IF someone should buy something.  Remember, pricing determines how good or bad a deal is, not the quality of the product being considered.  So now that I got that out of the way, let's begin.

I have enjoyed Royal Court thus far.  There has been a definite layer of depth added to the already great game-play.  If you enjoyed CK3 from different perspectives, cultures, challenges, etc this will not disappoint.  This takes all of what was already great and adds even more ways to play.  It does not however change how I feel about the game.  If you did not enjoy CK3 before, this content will do nothing for you in terms of changing that opinion.  I recommend this if you are a fan of CK3 and have the finances to spend on games.

Хорошее дополнение. Появилась масса новых ивентов и большее погружение в дела собственного двора. 

А теперь минусы: - 1) вылет может случиться в любой момент.
                                2) часто ссылки, решения, персонажей - нельзя посмотреть из окна ивента при наведении мышки. Особенно бесит при выборе новых решений, старые хоть помнишь. Проще говоря не открывается окно пояснений.
                                3) Проклики мышки. Тычешь мышкой звук есть, а ни чего не происходит или происходит не то что хотел. Особенно при осаде, хочешь выбрать войско, но вылезает окно осады. Часто звук нажатия мышки дублируется, а иногда и троится. 
                                4) В русской версии: ошибки, отсутствие перевода (вплоть до полного просто стоит ___name), какие то англ. обозначения.
                                5) Иногда нельзя снять игру с паузы. 
                                6) Шоу уродов. Особенно на востоке, там и до дополнения бегали сплошь опойные лица, теперь просто кошмар.
                                7) И не знаю как у других, но королевские приёмы у меня 99% состоят из решений: Вилкой в глаз или в *опу раз. 
                                                   
Очень, очень много технического брака.

110087637.review:
I thought the whole courtroom and artifacts business would feel like a bit of tacked-on busywork. But I was wrong, it absolutely adds some much needed life to the game. There is a ton of content there which flows quite well with what is happening outside the courtroom. It can have quite impactful consequences if you choose to accept them (you always get a choice). And while the adventures your courtiers go through to gain you new artifacts might not be the most immersive they're certainly entertaining.

I get that not everyone is convinced by the pricetag, but if you're buying Paradox DLC at full price you know what you're getting in to. Either get the Royal Edition at launch or wait for the inevitable sale if the price matters is that important to you. Personally I think it's worth it, it really fleshes out the game.

110078847.review: Royal Court is a decent expansion, but if you were burned out on CK3 already it doesn't do enough to make the game fresh again. I understand it was meant to draw players into the roleplaying mindset, but the court falls right in the middle of the uncanny valley, with all your courtiers and petitioners standing around, posed like mannequins, waiting for you to interact with them. The changes to the culture system are great. I was looking forward to launching my own unique, custom culture in game. But I can't overcome my deep sense of boredom long enough for the feature to mean something. If you are completely new to CK3 then Royal Court is probably worth picking up. If you're an existing player, you may wish to wait for several more expansions before coming back to it.

Parece poco contenido para un DLC que vale casi el mismo precio que el juego base, no obstante se agradecen el esfuerzo, sin embargo hay que reconocer que no cambia mayormente las dinámicas del juego y se esperaba un poco más. 
Algo a destacar, es que por fin se arregló el tema de los idiomas de las tradiciones que tanto pidió la comunidad latina. Por lo que ahora cambio mi voto a positivo

110073354.review:
My patience for paradox is starting to run thin, after waiting for months this dlc feels unpolished as usual. If this was the delayed product I truly fear what would have been launched three months ago. The features/foundations are solid but the price tag is quite absurd. The biggest problem with this update by far is the hits to the ai. The ai was already a bit shit but now its reaching new levels of incompetence. The culture change is good but it does often descend into chaos. Its just clear that the dev team is ignoring their play testers as they often do. The only paradox product that seems to be learning from their dev mistakes is Stellaris, with the open beta that's been going for the past few weeks which is rad. Thank you stellaris dev team for taking a step in the right direction. CK3 team learn from the stellaris devs and provide an open beta to people who pre-purchase the dlc, and listen to the feedback. The community needs to be more involved in development because I feel you have lost sight of what makes these games fun. I always buy paradox products but rather than being an enthusiastic fan I feel more and more disconnected from these games. 

This is nowhere near the shit show that is eu4 but its also far away from the kind of content I expect from a larger studio.

110060900.review:
This DLC is overpriced, yeah I get it. Who cares? This is paradox. People are willing to buy hearts of iron 4 dlc for 15 quid, when it should of been in the game in the first place. This is different, this is content that has never been before seen in any crusader king's titles, lets strip this down a bit into parts. The parts will go in order of what a normal player is likely to see to what a hardcore player is going to see.

Normal Player:
A normal player of this DLC will most likely only scratch the surface, the main bragging points of Royal Court are better cultures, courts with 3D MODELS!!!! And even a little bit of polish sprinkled on top, the first thing I noticed is that the map looks much, much cleaner and the models on the characters are just better somehow. It is hard to describe how great these features are, the less interesting feature (in my opinion) is the inventory system. It brings some very minor bonuses but its pretty cool from a RP standpoint. On a different subject, the RP potential and storytelling this DLC can provide is crazy, I would love to see a Game of Thrones mod with this DLC.

Ironman Player:
For those unfamiliar with Ironman mode, it does not allow saving and is pretty much considered hardcore mode. You will probably be able to reform, diverge or form a hybrid culture with your culture if you are specifically devoted. This can provide some cool bonuses too like "Malleable Invaders" which allows hybrid cultures in your realm to form more easily, and this slots in PERFECTLY with the Northern lords too. I suppose since this is a review I do need to beat up the DLC a little, they left tribal ruler's, dukes and counts out of the Courts of the DLC called "Royal court", this can make the expansion feel barebone's early game- Especially if you are going for achievements such as "Rags to riches" or "Mother of us all" which both start early game and usually in tribal realms. Now don't ask me why, but every game I have so far played has been on Iron Man mode, usually starting in a tribal realm. This expansion can feel non-noticeable at times and that does not bode well with the amount of people shitting themselves over the pirce. 

Hardcore Players- I don't consider myself a hardcore player, like a 1000 hours reddit moderator kind of person. The closets I have came to that is a near 200 hours, but that's probably just because when I first started playing this game I was engrossed like a child discovering a bottle with a thing that makes it look ever so slightly look like a rocket. 

My Opinion- This DLC is pretty good, I would not go as far to say it is brilliant. But it is moldbreaking in the sense that it gives the player new RP potential and better yet. custom dynasty banners. Many hours were spent making the Amogus banner, or maybe even the banner of house Lannister. But... I don't get why people are taking it in turns to kick paradox to the ground, like, you already gave them a solid blow to the jaw with the review's on "Northern Lords" and you all seem to have atleast 100 hours into the game, so suck it up, take it at face value and see what it really is- A cool DLC that adds cultures and 3D models, if this DLC is not for you, then I get that. But please, please don't go bitching about its price. This is paradox, and 2021 was a tough year for them.

110057433.review:
Recommending this DLC for one reason only - it's a great platform for mods. That's it. Vanilla Royal Court is absolutely pathetic. 

For DLC that has been delayed for as long as this one did, it's more than pathetic to have as few new events and limitations that make no sense. 

Do you think it'd be cool to focus on your courtly duties as a count/duke? Nope, only kings and emperors have a place to chill with their courtiers and their vassals just rules from the street, apparently (Fixed by mods) 

Do you want to play as an epic jarl why rules from his badass mead hall? Nope, Paradox thinks tribal governments were a bunch of savages with no concept of a court (Fixed by mods) 

"Oh well, they've spent so much time developing this DLC. Surely they must've made a lot of flavour events" you might think. Nope, there are about 5 events in your court, 10-15 "hold court" events and 5-ish world events. (Yet to be fixed by mods) 

All of it can be excused for a rushed DLC. This one has been delayed by almost a year! 
So get it for mods, but please spit on Paradox. 

Oh, also, inventory system is pretty neat, can't complain there.

110057408.review:
Два года.... Два года мы ждали DLC и что мы получили? 
Цена - конская, в половину самой игры (Впрочем, ничего нового. Paradox moment). На западе цена еще больше.

Артефакты: поначалу действительно интересно, однако чуть обдумав механ понимаешь, что что-то не так. И будешь прав. Хорошие артефакты можно получить только будучи королем-феодалом. Все остальные, к примеру, могут сделать за 100 голды топор на 1 доблесть и 0.01 престижа в месяц. Ну или на 2 доблести и +1 к отношению вассалов. Очень нужная вещь! 
Будучи королем и поддерживая вдохновленных персонажей (А это единственный способ получить +- неплохой артефакт), через некоторое время у вас будет уйма артефактов которые непонятно куда вообще девать. Продать/сломать их нельзя, есть возможность только передать какому-нибудь персонажу в дальних пердях молясь, чтобы это барахло к тебе не вернулось. Забыл добавить, что когда хочешь создать артефакт оружие, то ты не можешь выбрать что-то конкретное. Только 33% на топор или булаву или молот. А если я хочу ИМЕННО топор...? Почему нельзя выбрать что-то конкретнее?
Но больше всего 36ет мозги "Отец\Дед\Прадед, передайте мне ваш меч, а иначе -60 (ШЕСТЬДЕСЯТ КУРВА ШЕСТЬДЕСЯТ) к отношению". И самое смешное, что один и тот же персонаж с претензией на этот артефакт будет ухудшать с вами отношение так вечно. ОЧЕНЬ надеюсь, что это исправят каким-либо образом. Ставить людей из своего дома вассалами своей державы - это смерть. Да и если ваш сынок станет императором Византии, то тоже ничего хорошего. За отказ в выдаче топора на +1 к доблести (Ведь у него же претензия, забыли?), он снесет половину вашей страны.

Двор: Поначалу было интересно, но... Если честно, то сыграв пару игр ты понимаешь, что двор - это пустое хранилище для артефактов. Ты никак не можешь изменить что-то в своем дворе так, чтобы он выглядел действительно уникально. Нет почти никакой вариативности. Всего 3 вида двора (Европа, индия, ближний восток. Вроде ничего не забыл?). Повторюсь, ДЛЦ в стоимость половины игры, а в европе ценник еще гораздо выше... 
Со двором связано много новых ивентов, но, опять же, сыграв пару игр ты их заучиваешь и просто автоматически прокликиваешь нужные решения. Именно поэтому двор - просто хранилище артефактов.

Придворные: Появились новые роли для придворных. Наверное единственное, к чему претензий попросту (Во всяком случае у меня) нет. Как максимум - немного переделать баланс у некоторых придворных профессий. Иногда подбешивает "Конюший умер от кровавого пон0са" и надо постоянно искать замену.

Культуры: В целом - механика интересная. Но меня до сих пор мучает тот факт, что нельзя сделать смесь двух языков. Викинги в индии, при создании гибридной культуры, должны выбрать наследие (Либо индийское, либо северогерманское. Вроде логично, но почему нельзя сделать наследие общим..?), но вот язык... Либо все резко говорят на индийском, либо на северогерманском - возможности создать смешанный язык нету. Почему? В мире существует множество диалектов (А это - смесь нескольких языков, т.к несколько культур, грубо говоря, смешались) - в игре такого сделать нельзя. Нельзя создать смесь двух языков. Ну и почему же это тогда гибридная культура? 

DLC пусть и, в целом, понравилось. Но вспомнив цену и срок создания - оценка склоняется ближе к негативному... Я не упомянул еще кучу багов и глюков. Например сейчас появились мелкие глюки, которые не позволяют, если навестись мышкой на надпись, что дает тот или иной бафф от выбора в ивенте. (К примеру что дает бафф от стада или большого стада, если идти по пути управления). Или нельзя нажать на "плюсик" и узнать кто союзник (Ваш или врага) в нынешней войне. Персонажи выглядят сейчас как-то... Странно. У некоторых игроков вылетает игра/не запускается. Надпись розовым todo, когда осматриваешь некоторые функции своего двора. Делать дополнение 2 года и выпустить его сырым... Это мощно. Дополнение неплохое, но определенно надо ждать 1000 и 1-го обновления. Оценку ОБЯЗАТЕЛЬНЫМ образом сменю на положительную, если исправят глюки. Ну, желательно что-то сделать с артефактами...

110050315.review:
Оценивать буду неразрывно с изменениями патча 1.5.

Плюсы:

1. Интересные механики двора, которые призваны сдерживать игрока в финансовом плане и вносить разнообразие на поздних этапах игры.

2. Повышение роли культуры и введение культурного разнообразия между различными государствами. Система с языками вносит больший реализм, что тоже очень приятно.

3. Любопытная механика взаимодействия с артефактами (в частности, наличие системы претензий на артефакты и вытекающие из этого последствия).

4. Классная система создания своих гербов.

5. Душевное музыкальное сопровождение. Приятно порадовала новая музыка в главном меню, ну а кнопку «Устроить прием» в меню тронного зала я нажимаю в ожидании прекрасной атмосферной мелодии, сопровождающей сам прием.

Минусы:

1. Сроки выхода и политика DLC. Ситуация как с The Sims, когда после выхода новой части игры приходится ждать DLC с полюбившимся контентом. Разница лишь в том, что в The Sims возвращают животных и ночную жизнь, а в CK3 артефакты и редактор гербов.

2. Разнообразие нового контента. Почему так мало уникальных изображений для артефактов? Почему не все артефакты отображаются на персонажах? Что помешало добавить несколько вариантов тронных залов для различных культур? Ну и самое главное, что помешало сделать дворы (или их аналоги) для императоров и королей с племенным строем? Достаточно было добавить четыре-пять новых дворов (северный, средиземноморский, степной, восточный и африканский) для племен, написать для каждого четыре-пять уникальных ивентов, создать пару уникальных должностей и смотрелось бы уже намного лучше! Видимо это было сделано намеренно, чтобы продать такой контент потом в других DLC. 

3. Техническое исполнение. Сразу в топку все претензии о том, что не работают старые сейвы – это было очевидно, ибо игра поменялась слишком сильно. В принципе, пофигу на опечатки и глюки в переводе, это исправят. Но появились вылеты, ухудшилось качество лиц персонажей, в тронном зале 20-25 FPS, а автосейв стал занимать в два раза больше времени. Также есть более мелкие баги, по типу неправильного учета уровня учености персонажа в окне культуры, из-за чего переход в феодализм (и к новым механикам двора) откладывается на десятки лет. И все это с учетом переноса сроков выхода DLC.

4. Отсутствие латыни. Неужели нельзя было сделать основной язык Средневековья в игре про Средние века?...

Вместо итога:

Накопилось много вопрсоов. Почему, например, в новое DLC не включили напрашивающиеся механики коронации и регентства? Почему система оммажа (принесение клятвы вассалом сюзерену) слишком упрощена? Можно было бы сделать так, чтобы при появлении нового вассала (например, не ниже герцога) сразу бы вылезало окошко феодального договора, согласовывались бы условия, а затем вассал приносил бы оммаж в тронном зале, а мы бы дивились и радовались. Или чтобы вассал отваливался к другому сюзерену, если ему не нравилось у тебя, а ты бы мог объявить войну из-за потерянных земель. Также можно было бы заменить надоевшую упрощённую систему авторитета власти на более сложную систему законов из прошлой части, когда с советом приходилось делить полномочия по раздаче и отъему титулов, объявлению войны, аресту, казни и др.). Но, видимо, все это будет уже тема следующего крупного DLC, которое будет ждать нас… похоже, что через год-полтора, ибо разработчикам нужно еще Flavor Pack 2 выпустить, обещанный за предзаказ Королевского издания.

Я бы очень хотел, чтобы игра получила больше разнообразия и челленджа. Можно было бы вернуть систему защитных пактов, а также «Приключения монарха» из прошлой части, когда можно было за выполнение уникальных заданий за исторических личностей выбивать новые шапки, бороды и т.п. для персонажей. 

Но мои ожидания - это мои проблемы. 6.5/10.

110049695.review:
I agree with the consensus on this DLC. It's not bad, but the actual content here feels like it amounts to the patch that usually comes along side a major expansion, rather than an expansion itself. The two primary features here are firstly a court which does very little other than act as a money sink and a store room for items that mostly give you slight prestige bonuses. Secondly, it has culture modifications, which are more substantial but don't seem to offer a huge variance in play style. 

The problem with culture is it still hasn't really changed to be more notable from CK2, which is to say that it's almost irrelevant, providing minor or aesthetic changes rather than sweeping playstyle changes. Mercantile seafaring peoples get some extra income on the coast, highland warriors get some slight bonuses to combat in hills etc. The problem with bland bonuses like that is they don't change at all what you'll actually do in your game - Play a religion that has a lay clergy and you can hold temples. Pagans can raid while unreformed. See the difference between how religion is portrayed and how culture is? Culture feels like background fluff even in the places where it does provide benefits because it provides benefits that don't alter how you play. There's a city builder tradition in the game, but it still doesn't enable you to hold cities as a feudal.

Even for hit and miss DLC in CK2, they tended to change how you played substantially. The Horse Lords was a good example - I am one of the few who enjoyed the clan based government even though it was extremely rudimentary. At the very least it was an actual different experience. All of the CK2 governments felt substantially different to play as.

It does seem like the only reason this has been priced so high is that the court has actual visual representation. All it is at the end of the day is an abstraction of what CK2-3 already had: Events and interactions with other characters. It all seems like a serious overreach for something that doesn't add any new core gameplay experiences. 

CK3 doesn't need to be prettier, it needs more in it. The most important things to the game are religions and government types, and unfortunately that hasn't changed, culture still isn't really that important in that mix beyond what it already was. Which makes the choice to ignore expanding the currently limited options regarding government very strange on the part of Paradox as well.

110049364.review: At best this is a culture flavour pack. Certainly doesn't add anymore content than Northern Lords did. At worst this is a content light DLC because Paradox know most players with the Royal Edition paid before they knew what they were purchasing. What's included helps add flavour to the game, but it's not an expansion, and I'd not spend more than £10 on it.

110049121.review:
Even though the DLC is a pit overpriced it still adds a lot of interesting game mechanics. The royal court mechanic really makes your realm feel more alive, furthermore it adds more play to your economy, by constantly balancing the  level of court grandeur with the amount of gold you can miss. Furthermore, the new culture mechanic really allows for a more dynamic playstyle, that was previously not possible. The artifact system is a cool addition, however you can get so many useless artifacts that it may be difficult to find the ones that are actually good, it can make this system a bit tedious. Paradox should find a way to fix the sorting systems for artifacts because it does not appear to be working for me.

All in all I think the dlc itself is a lot of fun and adds many new elements to the game that were previsouly missing. It is a bit overpriced, but if you buy the royal edition of CK3 the dlc is definitely worth it.

110040002.review: TL;DR It feels like paying to take CK3 out of Early Access, not like paying for exciting extras. Look, I love Paradox games, and I consider this DLC essential to the game. So why can't I recommend it? Well it's not JUST the price. It's the fact that they've locked so many basegame features BEHIND such a highly priced DLC. They basically took stuff that was already part of CK2, waited like a year to add it to CK3, and then charged more than 50% of the basegame's price for it. You're not covering any new ground, you're just giving us back features we already have access to from a different game - Other than the 3D rendered royal court, which is cool but very incomplete. You can spend on amenities but nothing visibly changes about your court or courtiers when you get elite fashion or endless servants. When this is on sale for $5 then buy it. No hate toward the workers who made this, just ... The absolute upper limit I'd put on the value of this is $15 which is saying something because it includes what should have been CORE FEATURES of the game ON LAUNCH. The only thing that feels like it should be part of a DLC is the 3D rendered court, which probably took up most of their effort and isn't enough by itself to justify a DLC. The rest is arbitrarily paywalled mechanics you shouldn't have to play the game without. I am seriously concerned about the future updates to CK3 if they intend to keep locking basic features behind DLC paywalls that cost almost as much as the game itself.

110037481.review:
If you buy a Paradox game, it comes with the expectation that there will be paid DLC that supports the continued development and expansion of the game. So, I got the season pass  to get the first couple of DLC for free back when I got the game because I'm too impatient to wait for things to go on sale, and I play Paradox games, I know how this all works. So now that it's come out, it feels like I've gotten this DLC for free. Props to past me. 

The DLC is a blast! It adds a lot of flavor and variety, and just a lot more roleplaying and personality to the characters in the game. After several failed attempts I was able to re-enact the Norman Conquest and go about making London home to the grandest royal court in the world. Grand courts give a lot of positive modifiers, including to people's willingness to be recruited to your court, which gives a nice reliable way to invite talented people into your kingdom beyond marrying them in. 

Collecting artifacts is great fun, and balancing how much to spend on investing in your realm the old fashioned way versus getting nice new tapestries to hang up in your hall is pretty engaging. Some of the items you get are really powerful, especially in boosting prowess. With some famed armor and a famed weapon you're looking at well over +9 prowess, which you can pass down to your inbred fragile heirs to keep them alive. You can also gift artifacts to those clouts who hooked their way into your council, potentially buffing their doomed lines into some semblance of sentience. It's nice to see the nepotism of the medieval ages develop a couple of pros to balance the many many cons. 

The biggest criticism I have of the DLC is that I'd love to see more. I want to see more types of throne rooms, including a grand wooden feasting hall for tribals and norse Kingdoms. I want to see Empire titles unlock even more court positions and new mechanics in the same way reaching Kingdom opens up the court. I want more room to display my artifacts, I want more banners on the walls, an even larger court, more rooms to visit like the prisons and a treasury. Heck, medieval courts (especially pre 1066) often traveled, I'd love to be able to have more than one royal court, let me set up and decorate a winter palace separately from my summer palace, etc. The UI for gifting artifacts could and should also be improved.

That said, Royal Courts stands as an exciting addition to the game which adds a LOT of fresh content. Holding court is blast, the new events are great, commissioning artifacts is addictive. If you want to continue to support a gem of a game and have fun doing so, buy the DLC. If you can't afford it, wait for a sale, but this is definitely one you'll want to pick up at some point. I just hope that Royal Courts is the start of development in this direction, and not the only DLC we see that deepens the realms we govern.

110034970.review:
Overall a mess that is not worth the amount charged. 

- Royal Court is very ordinary and "meh" with only a handful of generic events. Courts are Eurocentric and aside from the architecture, nothing changes no matter where you are on the map. Nothing at all for Tribal kings, but they still get the penalties to vassal opinions? Completely breaks the game if you don't play Feudal essentially. 

- Artifacts are really generic and ordinary. Not really worth anything. 

- The culture mechanics, while a great idea that adds loads to the game, is very badly implemented. Many of the mechanics just aren't realistically usable due to insane costs and/or time constraints. This means these mechanics might as well not be in the game at all, making the entire thing a waste of time. 

Overall content is low, and aside from the graphics assets with Royal Court, appear to mostly be low effort. You can cover the entire DLC in the first hour of gameplay. Making it boring and pointless. 

On launch are insane bugs, such as invincible AI armies, regular crashes, save file corruptions, AI getting stuck in endless wars etc. etc.

You can tell that not only did they not test the game properly, they have actually not played the game to see if their mechanics are even viable. It feels like a couple of people slapped this together in their weekends or something.

If this DLC had cost maybe $10 and was much better balanced making the content actually usable, it would be ok and I'd give it a thumbs up. But for the price being charged, is a complete and utter ripoff. 
Get this in a humble bundle or on 90% discount sale or something.

110034263.review:
Like most Paradox DLCs, wait for a discount before buying. Its does provide a new shallow depth to the game but definitely not worth 30 dollars. Though I have a distinct feeling this is just a ploy by paradox to get people to do their DLC subscription service by making these shoddy expensive dlcs and make it seem like a cheaper alternative to spend 5 bucks a month than 30 up front.

The royal court system just feel empty, with only one or two events popping up every few years. Holding court just gives you 3-4 decision events that cause little effects to your wider realm and at times feel sloppily thrown together. I once had a count requesting vassalage under me and then the very next person, happens to be his kid brother requesting me to declare war on my new vassal and place him as count. Then after that, you gotta wait for another 5 years for another 4 events. You get 21 new courts positions, but if you go into your court the max amount of people you really see are 10 randos middling about. 
The relic system also feel mediocre. In your court you are allowed only 3 Banners, 3 small trophy, 3 furniture and 4 centerpieces with only two distinct types of relics, court and personal (which you can equip). You can turn your personal relic into a court relic but not the other way around. So if you want to wear the Crown of Justinian as you lead your empire, you can't because its only purpose is to be on display in 1 of 4(!!!!) slots in your court. So as a large empire with 20 plus relics, you're really not displaying the power and majesty of your court and more showing off a bit of nick knacks to your house guests. If I was a successful warlord, why can't I carpet the path to my thrones with the fallen banners of my enemies?

So save your money! Wait for the next christmas sales.

I wish there was a maybe option for recommending things on Steam. I don't want to say that I don't recommend this, because I did enjoy this expansion. But at the same time, it doesn't feel right to recommend it in it's current state/pricing.
I'll summarise: 

1. Is it fun? - Yeah, adding actual 3D spaces to see your characters in gives the world a more 'lived in' feel. I', very curious to see how they would expand on this in future, adding more 'scenes' as it were e.g. banquet hall, battle fields, council chambers etc..
That being said, I personally feel that the real 'meat' of this expansion has nothing to do with the Royal Court itself, but rather the much requested culture rework. Also seems weird to exclude tribal rulers from having a court. You wanna tell me Genghis Khan didn't have a court? And why is there no native freecam option? I wanna see my grossly inbred King's face up close dammit!

2. Was it worth waiting for? - Depends on how long you were waiting for it. If you count from when they started selling the 'Royal Edition' prior to the base release that's almost two years. Obviously Covid threw a wrench into everything, but even so, I don't think the amount of content added by this DLC justifies how long people have had to wait for it. This is something that absolutely cannot be repeated by Paradox.

3. Is it worth the price? - LOL NO. See above. This is the most expensive DLC Paradox have ever released. Hell I got this through the Royal Edition and I feel a little shortchanged by it. Just wait until it goes on sale. I would not under any circumstances recommend buying this for full price.

110004122.review:
It's hard for me to write the DLC does not add lot's of new gameplay after a few more hours in.
So far I've commissioned several new artifacts, diverged and hybridized cultures, decorated my court and even sent courtiers abroad on adventurers.
Beyond the surface features, you interact with your court and realm in new and more personal ways. Instead of yelling at your courtiers in a few events you are now represented living in your realm, the DLC makes the game much more personal to your character. 
The content added on it's own is subtle yet impactful on your realm, adding as much flavor as functionality.. yet the additional content is not 'tacked on'.. it changes the base game into something much more personal, intimate, and direct. You will feel and notice the change in the game. While not everything it could have been.. it is the first step into what CK3 will be - and for that it's worth the buy, but it's not everything you want it to be.

110001382.review:
[h1] A DLC of Great Grandeur [/h1]

TL;DR If this DLC is reasonably priced is for you to decide, but it sets out to be the most ambitious DLC yet and in that it succeeds.

It’s hard to develop DLC for a sequel to a beloved game like Crusader Kings 2. On the one hand if you only add features already present in the prequel, people are miffed to be paying for the same features all over again. But if you only add completely new features people will start complaining about your priorities and form factions to demand their favourite feature be added to the game right now.
To circumvent this problem Paradox decided on a compromise for Royal Court, adding a completely new dynamic culture system, a 3D throne room, and reintroducing a fan favourite: artifacts.
Royal Court is considered the first major DLC for Crusader Kings 3, with a grand price tag of $30. This sets the bar high for Royal Court. To meet expectations, it must try to be more ambitious than any CK2 DLC ever was. Let’s see if it succeeds at this.

[b] Culture system [/b]
At launch Crusader Kings 3 distinguished itself from its predecessors by having a dynamic faith system. It not only had more religions, but also allowed players to start their own religion, greatly improving replay value and the RPG potential of the game.
With Royal Court a similar system is implemented for culture. Cultures are no longer one-dimensional but consist of various cultural pillars. Players and AI can now reform these pillars over time. Most significant of these pillars are the traditions. A culture can have up to 5 traditions at game start and there is a large amount of them in the game giving access to a variety of bonusses and mechanics. Most traditions are meaningful, and a well customized culture can greatly help lean into a certain playstyle.
Reforming a culture is not the only way cultures change in the new system. There is also the possibility of diverging from your culture. Diverging a culture is instantaneous and allows for faster customization if prestige is plentiful. As such it does lack the long-term planning that comes with reforming a culture. A third option is hybridizing, merging two cultures. Like diverging, hybridization is instantaneous, but does require some long-term planning as certain amount of cultural acceptance is needed before hybridization is possible.
With the added complexity of languages, ethoses and traditions to culture and with the addition of three ways to dynamically change cultures, Royal Court adds a lot of content and greatly increases the replayability. With this new culture system Royal Court proves it is willing to take an ambitious leap and back it up with quite the amount of content.

[b] Royal Courts [/b]
Also new with this DLC is its namesake, the royal court, visualized as a 3D throne room filled with courtiers. This space is used to stage some events in and represent the state of your court, abstracted to a value called grandeur. Grandeur can range from 0 to 100 and is mostly decided by your willingness to spend money on it, either through amenities or hiring people to fill court positions. Because money is relatively easy to come by in CK3, grandeur isn’t hard to max out. Because of this and the fact that an increase in grandeur only results in bonusses, there isn’t really any trade-off to grandeur and doesn’t present the player with any meaningful choice.
The virtual throne room looks visually stunning and does succeed in making the court feel more alive, expanding the RPG aspect of CK3 further. The court is however only visible in a window separate from the map where players will spend most of their time. To counter this the developers added events that pop-up in this window and the decision to hold court that present the player with a string of events, but players might find they still only occasionally check the court window.
With the addition of the royal court the developers take a risk by adding something very few people requested. It’s an ambitious step to utilize Clausewitz 2’s 3D capacity and elevate the game’s role-playing capabilities. But because players will only spend a limited time in the virtual court, there is only just enough content to justify it as a feature. Hopefully future DLC and patches will expand on this feature and give the player more stuff to do at court.

[b] Artifacts [/b]
One thing visible in your court not mentioned yet are artifacts. A first for Crusader Kings, artifacts actually show up as 3D models when added to a court. The virtual court is however not the only place artifacts might be collected. Characters also have a personal inventory, where artifacts that can be carried on their person are represented. Artefacts are primarily acquired via inspired characters, who can be sponsored to start crafting items, and there is an assortment of events that determine the outcome of the crafting process.
The total number and variety of artifacts added in Royal Court match those of CK2, even though CK2 needed multiple DLC to get to the same amount. This quantity of artifacts shows Royal Court is willing to go the extra mile to catch up and possibly even overtake CK2 DLC content.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
Having reviewed all this, we return to the question of if Royal Court adds more content than any of CK2’s DLC did, as its price tag seems to indicate. The answer to that question could be yes, especially when considering the amount of 3D models included in this DLC. Though the amount features added is limited, the culture system and artifacts especially are supported by an impressive amount of content.
Does this mean that $30 is a reasonable price to pay for Royal Court? That is a question only you can answer and one which heavily depends on your interest in the included features. It is undoubtedly a hefty sum to pay for a DLC, but if any Crusader King DLC is worth $30, it is Royal Court.
One important caveat is that this DLC does focus quite strongly on feudal kings and emperors and forgets about vassals and tribal rulers. While playing as a tribal or vassal can be just as interesting as playing a feudal king, Royal Court barely expands gameplay for these particular playstyles as they do not have access to courts or court artifacts.

109992545.review:
老实说新版本的玩法还不错，但是我还是要给差评。
为什么呢？
因为新版本最有意义的文化机制是免费的，90块就买了个无脑拉满的宫廷。
P社，你是做大战略出身的还是做RPG出身的？
你擅长什么心理没点数吗？
90块的价格，一年多的工期，这就保证了我不可能给他好评。
好了，骂也骂过了，说点好的吧。
新版本的文化机制很有趣，文化融合和分离系统是个好玩的机制。
大量的传统，事件和文本也给了玩家很大的代入和脑补空间。
这方面我可以推荐一个知乎的架空国家企划，摩诃契丹。
原本机制不允许，需要玩家自己丰富的文化，建筑，美学传统现在有了官方的机制，这是好的。
新版本的宫廷事件我不是很喜欢，但是先不提5年一次的朝会和数量爆炸的宝物。
宫廷显赫度和宫廷语言是个很有趣的设计。
原本CK2的机制无法模拟中世纪晚期各国以法语为荣，法兰西化的情况，只能把领主强行设置为法兰西文化。
但是新dlc的宫廷语言和文化语言脱钩，可以很好的模拟出历史上的情况。
嗯......还有不少想说的，但是无关紧要。
CK系列是我最喜欢的游戏系列，希望能越做越好吧。


对了......再稍微提一下我想要的内容：
增加贸易与物产系统，细化封建契约，允许自建特殊建筑，允许垦殖修改地形，增加文化和宗教沉浸事件，增加可玩剧本和时间线。
CK3有一个很好的框架，但是如果摆烂的话是没有意义的。

Минусы:

- 1) Культуры. Постоянные уведомления о том, как очередной узбек соединился с таджиком... Уммм да, это именно то, чем мне нужно засорять мой экран.

- 2) Артефакты. Постоянно какой-нибудь бомж делает тебе корону на +0.1 престижа, за которую на тебя потом нападут твои соседи. Ну и бред, надеюсь когда-нибудь это пофиксят. И САМОЕ ТУПОЕ ЧТО АРТЕФАКТ НЕЛЬЗЯ ВЫКИНУТЬ ИЗ ИНВЕРТАРЯ! Приходится 60 лет ждать, когда этот кусок металлолома, именуемый "Корона _культура-нейм_ народа" сгниёт от своей никчёмности и недоработаности.

- 3) Монарший двор. Безжалостный пожиратель фпс и времени с кучей однообразных ивентов. В плане геймплея провал полный. Но выглядит красиво, тут ничего не скажешь......

Плюсы:

+ 1) Культуры. Механику культур разнообразили крайне годно. Гибридизация и отделение культур - реально то, чего не хватало в игре, и как по мне является главной фишкой длс.

+ 2) Артефакты. Конкретнее - ивенты на поиск артефактов. Или же так называемые путешествия. Если вы играете не за племя, то у вас может вдохновиться рандомный гость/придворный и он отправится в путешествию в какую-нибудь Великую Степь. Мне ивенты этих путешествий очень понравились и стали, пожалуй, самыми любимыми ивентами всей ЦК3 на сегодняшний день. Жаль только, что все остальные ивенты вдохновлённых персонажей, например на ковку оружия, не такие захватывающие. И ещё меня напрягло, что я за одну партию три раза подряд выбил с путешествий в Великую Степь ветвь Древа жизни, который даёт чёткие бонусы для даосов, а для всех даёт +1 престижа. Но это не так критично, в целом путешествия вдохн. персонажей для меня стало плюсом. 

+ 3) Монарший двор. В интерфейс монарш. двора я захожу примерно 1-2 раза за всю партию, но каждый раз было приятно посмотреть, как выглядят твой персонаж вместе с придворными, особенно когда ты только перешёл из племени в феодализм. 

в общем как ты понял длс спорное. но если ты хочешь потратить последние 500рублей на это то в принципе твоё дело, люди и так по своей природе глупы и поэтому это будет вполне естественным шагом.

109983494.review:
TL:DR: I think that the DLC, while fun, is purposefully overpriced to try and get people to buy the expansion pass. 

I personally have had a lot of fun with this DLC, from forming Indian Vikings who raid overseas with war elephants, to making the kingdom of Sardinia a quasi-trade republic by reforming their culture to have bonuses to ports, farms, and guilds. However, for what is on offer here, I find the price that it's at to be too high, mainly because I want more out of $30. However, I think this is the point. 

If you go and check the price of the season pass, at the time of writing this, it is about $35 before any discounts. It's going to be worth watching the price of that season pass, because if it goes up by the time I'm writing this, then Paradox may be trying to get people to buy a more expensive season pass in order to get a little extra out of customers before any other dlc/flavor-pack/whatever get's released in the first place. The pass was $35 before royal court or northern lords ever came out, and if it goes up, then, to me, it's confirmed that they're trying to prey on people who think, "yea, the season pass is more expensive, but it means I'll get access to future updates and not get left behind with something that is overpriced."

To sum it up, if you REALLY want this dlc now, get the season pass. If you are willing to wait for sales, then please do so, and if the price of that season pass DOES go up, then, Paradox, that seems like a really slimy marketing strategy. 

Looking back at it now, that might be why Northern Lords is $15 dollars as well.

EDIT: Northern Lords isn't $15. That's my bad.

109978574.review:
Would highly recommend to any CK3 player who is looking for more to add to their game. I feel like people are not truly appreciating how big of a deal the 3D throne room is. I have been dreaming of something that added exactly this since release of CK2. Adds the final level of immersion that gets you lost in your sandbox world, cultures and characters feel way more dynamic and well real.

As it stands, even with the price tag, personally I think it add a lot of flavour, suddenly characters come alive with the court and the events seem way more natural and memorable since you trigger certain events from your court, outside of holding court. Haven’t had a lot of time to fully flesh it out but it seems to run well and provide a lot unique artefact events as well as other unseen possibilities.

The only cons I see are it is limited the royal court to only kings and emperors, also you need to be feudal so a big chunk of the map doesn’t really benefit and I personally prefer being a dukedom or duke under a king, at least to start. But I imagine this will get added later on with DLCs probably and more flavour packs.

If you play Paradox games you know what to expect. In the end this is one of the better DLCs I’ve ever bought from them. For sure a lot of mechanics and flavour that add a lot to the game, expensive but if you have the cash and are eager to game, I think it is worthwhile. It won’t break your game or anything strange. 

I felt the strong need to add a positive comment because I am tired of seeing the toxic and angry part of the Paradox community just downvote released like mad just because it is expensive or they don't think it is enough. The answer is simple enough for people who don't like what the company is doing, just stop buying the game or what for a sale. But stop just spamming downvotes because you don't like the DLC model. If you don't understand it by now please just go play Minecraft.

I will discuss the pricing of this DLC later but first I want to hit upon the stability. It was delayed for stability and I am fine with that however I guess it should have been delayed a bit longer. I can not play a game for more than 20 minutes with out one of the following happening; Game stops responding, Crash report window pops up, Computer freezing, or my favorite BSOD. At first my crash reports tried to do the very best they could but after submitting around 20 they may have devolved into "Trying to play the game."

Now for the price, this game costs more than half the base game and as such I expected a fair transformative product. However even if we take into account the free update [which I am not since most of it is there to support the paid content] this is not worth the price. I did not play CK2 but from what I have gathered they are adding back functionality from a previous title slowly. But honestly aside from the court positions that are part of the free game I don't think there is much here. 

I was gifted the DLC for my birthday since it came out a day before and I feel like the person that bought it for me got robbed That is how wholly inadequate I think this product is for the price. It is probably more at home at around 12.99 but it is hard to justify any more than that.

Perhaps my opinion will change in the future, infact I hope it does. I guess my final closing statement is please delay things until they are done, you have been doing the people who purchase your DLC dirty lately and we all know it. Shape up or we ship out.

109968630.review:
[h1]Overpriced, oversold, overworked.[/h1]

Over the past few years, Paradox has more often than not released DLC that has failed to meet consumer expectations. Paradox developers have noted the challenges of dealing with COVID-19 and working from home arrangements, but their decline in quality and the overpricing of DLC begins as early as EU4's The Cossacks (for which I wrote a very lengthy negative review, hence why I specifically remember it), released nearly 7 years ago at the end of 2015. COVID-19 is not the problem.

At pain of making this review far longer, I could continue on about my speculations regarding Paradox Development Studios and how it's operated, and why this is causing problems. But reviews have a character limit, so I will reserve my remarks on PDS to this: STRATEGISE your time better, re-evulate how you value features, do not assume more time = more value.

[b]The DLC's added content: is it good?[/b]

It's just... okay. You couldn't say the content is 'awful'; the added depth to cultures is a welcome addition, the inventory and combat systems something I missed from CK2 and glad to have back, and the new royal court and its many new positions fairly mediocre but not [i]awful[/i] features.

Is the new content enjoyable, though? Not really. Not that it has made the game less enjoyable, but I can't say it has made the game more enjoyable either. The way I play CK3 hasn't really changed from before Royal Court. The features, though not awful, feel  "tacked on". They don't offer new ways to play, but merely supplement the existing gameplay loop. Aside from needing to keep your court's grandeur above the expected threshold, you could validly completely ignore your royal court and it would make no serious impact upon gameplay.

Engaging with your royal court also becomes quite tedious. I was surprised to find after checking CK3's Royal Court event files that there are 86 (as I counted) general royal court events, yet while playing it feels as though there are only 10-15. The issue is that many events rely upon specific conditions that are unlikely to change throughout a character's life. Many, for example, rely upon certain court positions being occupied, but as a vast majority of them cost 0.50 to 1.50 gold to upkeep, it is simply too expensive to have more than a handful of courtiers employed at any given time until the late game (by which time, given how easy CK3 is, most have stopped playing out of boredom). Consequently, you are faced with the same set of events again and again.

I'd also note that it [i]seems[/i] a majority of court events are negative, usually resulting in you losing money, prestige, and relations with one or more vassals. Positive outcomes are rare and not rewarding enough when holding court more often leads to negative outcomes. Events where gold is lost is especially harsh when your court grandeur threshold requires dedicating almost your entire income to court amenities.

And, on that note, the cost of court amenities and salaries scale awfully. Tying court costs to eras results in expense hikes completely disconnected from the pacing of the game. Income game design has been made to grow gradually as you invest in buildings and increase county development over time, but the +25% hike in court costs is instantaneous upon entering a new era. To use my current game starting as West Francia as an example, I formed the empire of Francia and rule over essentially eight de jure kingdoms. This makes my court grandeur expectation level 10, meaning I essentially need full court amenities. Going from Tribal to Early Medieval instantly increased my court amenities cost by 10 gold and made many of the court positions I had filled no longer affordable to maintain as their salaries also hiked by +25%.

This meant I needed to make many court positions vacant, meaning less interaction with courtiers and less event flavour, as well as it disrupting the flow of gameplay completely as I had to suddenly shift towards buildings and development all of a sudden without any graduality- a shift that is hard to do, given its reliance on stable income and time. I don't feel as though this janky kind of gameplay is the kind of gameplay intended, especially given how disjointed it is from CK3's game design approach to income.

Final issue I have with the royal court is the royal court view itself. Court artefacts, especially pedestal artefacts, look awkwardly out of place. After filling out all the artefact slots, your court more resembles a museum storeroom than it does a royal court. It begs the question why this feature was even implemented when it really serves no purpose.

I recall reading in a dev diary that a significant amount of coding went into adapting the engine so that the royal court could be visually represented. [i]Why?[/i] Several times in the past (after repeated controversies around pricing) Paradox has justified the price of their DLCs upon the time and effort they invested into developing them. The issue with such an approach is obvious: consumers don't value time and effort, they value quality and content.

Accounting for how feature-poor this [i]very expensive[/i] DLC is, I can't help but feel Paradox felt justified in their pricing due to the time they poured into coding and troubleshooting the engine to support the court visuals. Not only are these visuals very [i]average[/i] and completely lacking responsive variation (why doesn't my court change when I pour money into luxury amenities? why doesn't it look like a rundown shelter when I neglect it?), it serves zero gameplay function. Here, I believe, Paradox made a HUGE misjudgement, placing far too much value in the visuals.

CK3 is a [i]grand strategy game[/i]. While the visual representation of characters is highly appropriate for CK3's core gameplay, it being centred around the lives of individuals, it was unnecessary to extend that as far as visually representing the royal court, especially when doing so was so costly and needing further development of an already greatly functional engine. Frankly, it was a complete waste of time and money.

I think most players would have been equally as satisfied with simply a flat interface similar to the inventory system that represented the artefacts on display in their court, not needing the extensive effort that was invested into showcasing those artefacts visually. Interacting with characters in this interface is a hopeless affair. It has never been helpful and I continue to use either the council panel or courtiers panel. In fact, more often it becomes an inconvenience, as the intuitive and fantastic tooltip system CK3 introduced to Paradox's games doesn't work as fluidly with the royal court interface, it blocking the display of panels and requiring me to exit the court view during court events to check a character's aptitude for court positions they're requesting, or to check titles relevant to a court event as the title panel is also completely blocked when in the royal court view.

I believe the crux of this DLC's issue lies in the decision to have the royal court visualisation. If all the time and effort that went into implementing new engine code instead was dedicated to new mechanics, interactions, and flavour, there is no doubt this DLC would have been better received. The fact that the Northern Lords flavour pack actually changed the gameplay loop by offering new ways to play by varying choices and interactions, while this mainline major expansion fails to do so and sits more as an idle supplement and less a game changing major expansion, says a lot to how significantly those who direct Paradox's projects misunderstand what makes their games fun, engaging, and replayable.

Paradox Development Studios HAS talented staff, capable of making quality products, but I believe PDS's management of time and valuation of features is deeply flawed. They MUST improve their strategy. This spiral must end.

109958434.review:
An essential addition to the Crusader Kings 3 experience. 

First I'll address the reason why the DLC has been review bombed,

The price of Royal Court might be a little steep for some, but the DLC helps fund the free patch content. A lot of the issues people have expressed in regards to the pricing wouldn't have been expressed if the free patch content was included with the expansion under the same price, and not available for all. You're basically getting half the DLC content for free, but you can pay for the *full* thing (including the free content) if you want it. It helps to fund the continued development of the game, which allows Paradox to continue to support their games for as long as they do.

Plus, if you have a group of friends you play with consistently, only one of you (the host) needs to own the DLC.

With that out of the way,

POSITIVES
- fits seamlessly into the standard CK3 gameloop and doesn't feel like a gimicky add-on
- seeing the characters in court and interacting with them brings them to life and makes you care about them a lot more
- gives you more to do during down-time and adds a lot of flavour to the game, which was sorely needed
- very pretty 3D models

NEGATIVES
- at present the artifacts system, which is a base game feature but featured most prominently in the expansion, focuses too much on generic and low-level items, and artifact bloat is even worse than in Crusader Kings II
- some minor issues with polish and bugs, particularly in loc texts which has some spelling and grammar issues, though we can expect these to be fixed with time

109958347.review:
After so many failed expansions I was finally having hope for a return to form, but I'm once again bitterly disappointed. This feels like a minor patch, not a $40 PLUS expansion.

The court itself is remarkably barren and almost entirely cosmetic.
Artefacts you collect are represented with generic 3d models that do not resemble the item itself in any way, this could be a glitch but I'm 99% sure this is just working as intended. Eg, a small bust I found is represented by a bronze eagle statue.
Your weapons and armour do not even appear on your character, what is the point of this? Why bother forging or collecting a rare sword or piece of armour if you can't see it in-game outside of the 2d icon representing it in the menu.

Once again we have an absurdly overpriced "expansion" that offers very little, which is exactly what I've come to expect.

109944967.review:
Перед первым запуском нового DLC я был полон скепсиса и ожидал гораздо худшего продукта. Принимая во внимание невысокое качество последних дополнений к другим играм студии, я уже не верил, что игра получит интересный контент и пробудится от летаргического сна. Долгие полтора года разработки и скриншоты с весьма спорными игровым решениями не внушали большого оптимизма. Тем не менее, Парадоксам удалось дать игрокам слабую надежду, а меня убедить что на студии не стоит ставить крест. 

Дополнение порадовало добавлением новых интересных особенностей — культуры, языки, реликвии, редактор гербов. Появился бóльший простор для ролеплея и написания интересной истории своей династии. Реконструкция языков и культурных особенностей средневековых народов относительно неплоха — с поправкой на обычный "историзм" парадоксов (всё остальное в руках мододелов). Очень порадовала работа композитора и добавление свежих композиций, вносящих небольшое разнообразие в пресное аудиооформление игры.
Основная "фича" — тронный зал правителя. Он показался мне абсолютно бесполезным нововведением, оттянувшим на себя изрядную часть сил и ресурсов при разработке DLC. Смешные маленькие фигурки персонажей, сидящие на высоких тронах, шаблонность и несуразность застывших поз дворни, ограниченность "коробок" палат с несколькими ракурсами камеры — всё это в 2022 году выглядит очень странно для гранд стратегии и уже крайне несовременно.

Что до самой игры, то в неё по-прежнему невозможно играть. Что-то удалось починить при разработке этого дополнения, но большая часть негатива и откровенного бреда игрового процесса по-прежнему с нами, приобретя в довесок множество багов и нестабильных механик. ИИ всё так же не умеет воевать: плохо распоряжается своими войсками и влезает в большие долги. Государи всего лишь марионетки в руках у фракций нобилитета, во многих племенах и странах правителями становятся женщины, а все без исключения крупные государства разваливаются просто по щелчку пальцев. Балканизация множества регионов огромной карты не исключение, а правило. 
Очень печально, что за полтора года разработки хотя бы не потестили и не стабилизировали эти игровые аспекты. Как всегда бывает у Парадоксов — после релиза долгая и упорная работа над ошибками.

Несмотря на то, что сейчас в Crusader King III можно играть только будучи мазохистом, новое дополнение позволяет надеяться, что игра не заброшена, её постепенно оживляют и немного добавляют новые интересные аспекты. Печалит скорость разработки, которая явно не пропорционально результату. Дополнение, хоть и с оговорками, буду рекомендовать — игра скорее жива, чем мертва. Надеюсь, что через год или полтора в следующем DLC всё же починят административную политику, военное управление или добавят (эрзац-) экономику.

Я верю, что когда-нибудь у меня получится сыграть в CKIII, как во вторые кресты, и получить похожие впечатления и эмоции.

109940703.review:
Very recommended DLC.  Worth every penny.  The amount of depth added by custom cultures adds a lot for a player like me who likes to experiment with "ahistorical" builds.  Further adding onto the already customized religions, you can really fine tune your realm for whatever you goal is on any particular run.  Culture blending in particular looks like it can get really crazy.

The Court itself brings back a mechanic from CK2 that I sorely missed, Artifacts.  Stack wiping West Francia and taking their Battle Flag to hang on my wall was an official "Awesome Moment In Gaming" for me.

I even like the language mechanic.  Is your different cultured wife a little disinterested?  Learn her language.  Helps for making friends with hostile neighbors too.  I also used it as the final straw to push a foreign king into accepting a betrothal.

More options and flexibility in nearly every aspect of the game.  Simply put this is exactly what a DLC should be.  For 30 dollars I've tacked at least another 1000 hours onto a game that was starting to feel stale when it dropped.

109940378.review:
While I received the DLC through the Expansion Pass on Pre-Order, the pricing on this is completely absurd. I enjoy the DLC and find much of the content a welcome addition to the game. It is a good start to the Ck3 content and includes a lot of features that flesh out the already excellent base game. 

However, this is Paradox's most expensive DLC and do not forget that word 'DLC', while this is marketed as an expansion it is just more content. If this had many more mechanics and actual gameplay styles I would perhaps consider the price worthy. But it is not. It is far more expensive than additions such as Old Gods for CK2, Utopia for Stellaris, Art of War for EU4 and Waking the Tiger for HoI4 while not nearly being as important as any of these.

I understand that CK3 is supposed to be the next generation of Paradox Games and is consequently going to be much more expensive. However, the quality of the product must match the price. Paradox's DLC policy has always been unwelcoming and harsh to newcomers. If the rest of the 'expansions' are like Royal Court, than this situation will only make things much worse while hurting loyal players. I simply cannot recommend this expansion at this price and I do hope that Paradox re-evaluate this policy.

109938533.review:
Чувствуете этот запах? Так пахнет копеечная покупка из китайского онлайн-магазина.

Что можно представить себе, когда слышишь про "предметы в CK3"? Церковные реликвии, мощи святых, паломники толпами стекаются в собор, чтобы припасть к святыне, древние предметы, которые подтвердят претензию короля на происхождения от легендарных героев. Ну или хотя бы блеск двора и по-настоящему драгоценные подарки аристократам.

Что мы получаем тугой струёй в наше наивное лицо?

Как насчёт термина "хранилище артефактов" в игре про средневековье? Не "сокровищница", нет. Даже не "хранилище реликвий", а, мать их, артефактов! "Поздравляю,  вы поставили себе фэнтези-рпг с эконом-дизайном.

А как мы взаимодействуем с "артефактами"? Можно надеть, можно снять. Можно поставить в комнатку. Можно убрать из комнатки. Кстати, не забудь простукивать "артефакты" молоточком. И всё? Не знаю, может быть проколупавшись лет 300 (каждые пять лет "приём", не забудь!) нам откроются невероятные возможности, и "боевую палку древних оборванцев" можно будет изукрасить каменьями и золотом, чтобы получился великий императорский артефакт! Или нет.

Да, не забудьте, если вы не король и не император, то тумбочка вам не положена. Извините, но реальность такова, что мебель - удел королей. И книжки. И облезлая шкура козла на +10 к крутости комнатки тоже. "Не могу взять в руки, беда-то какая!"

Зато у короля есть комнатка. Там нам покажут болванчиков, которые изображают жизнь. Огромный выбор! Несколько сценок, иллюстрирующих, что кнопку вызова текстового квеста надо нажать, потому что там СМЫСЛ. Ого, компьютерная женщина разговаривает с компьютерным мужчиной, это важно - ведь у нас три выбора: два на минусы и один на плюс.

"Потрясающая" механика приёмов: нажмите на кнопку, чтобы получить три текстовых квеста в один ход. Удобно, чёрт возьми, раз в пять лет надо прокликать и получить свой законный бонус или немного расстроиться.

Да, квесты одностраничные: описание можно не читать, предлагается выбрать вариант с бонусами или минусами. Естественно, никакой внятной визуализации квеста не будет.

Визуально комнатка замечательная: нам показывают одну статичную комнатушку, в которой сидит ЦАРЯ ВО ДВОРЦА, а вокруг пошатываются "придворные". Больше ничего не происходит, кроме возможности расставить полтора десятка предметов по своим ячейкам, чтобы получить плюсики (не забудь простукать молоточком). Зато в три-дэ, ОГО!

А, нам же добавили ДВОР! Теперь мы можем видеть, кого назначили подавальщиком левого носка и какие от этого бонусы. Кроме бонусов практически ничего не происходит, даже механика охоты практически не изменилась (А, вы уже понадеялись, что охота будет королевской? Хаха, не изменилось ничего вообще, кроме цифорок).

Также нам расширили культурку, тут даже в плюс, хотя всё также работает весьма топорно. То, что у нас могут одни с другими пережениться, что у нас лингва-франка заводится само собой, никого не интересует. Пока батя не скажет смешаться, никакого смешения! Отсутствие смешения черевато минусами в циферках и периодическими восстаниями: "Мы тут выяснили, что царь - немец! Мы категорически против!"

Языки работают точно также смешно: поинтригуй, чтобы выучить язык, кубики выпали, и вот ты уже его знаешь (впрочем, это хотя бы не одностраничный квест). Толмачи? Зачем? Язык нужен для циферок!

Так что теперь промотка времени разбавлена чуть большим количеством простеньких текстовых квестов, довольно однообразных, достаточно прокликать ответ с лучшими циферками, периодическими протыкиваниями "заплатить, чтобы вдохновение работало" и подобной ерундой (не забудь простукать молоточком артефакты).

Я буду очень счастлив, если такая безблагодатность случилась по причине того, что всех, кого можно бросили на штурм редута третьей виктории, иначе это ДЛЦ выглядит крайне пугающе!

ДОВЕСОК: я сейчас посмотрел - некоторые придворные в сцене "приёма" имеют наглость стоять к королю задом. Постановщиков сцен надо на конюшню и высечь за непочтительность.

- New systems that adds flavor: Courts, Customization of Banners/Crests
- Tons of new ways to play the game with 10+ new Court Positions and Culture divergences.
- Great Mod-Support, playing the DLC with supported mods can increase the size of it ten-fold. (The mods are also high quality, just look through the Crusader Kings 3 Twitter Feed)

Cons:
- Can feel a little extra spammy with pop-ups at times
- The 'Hold Court' Interaction and Random Court Interactions sometimes feel pointless, tedious and may take more away than it gives.

People need to chill with their ranting about the price-tag.
This DLC changes your entire game, and it comes with a free major update for anyone less interested.
All cultures are changed with new systems, fundamentals and progressions, which changes the flow of your -entire- playthrough. 
They did it in a good way too, that adds depth but doesn't make it tedious. 
The artifacts are nice rounded system, which if you truly dig into, can boost and bolster your entire empire to almost overpowered extremes. 

Suggestions for improvement:
- Change the court scene in an Empire, so that it doesn't just appear as a Kingdom Court
- More customizations options for the court itself, so that we may make it a bit more personal (beyond artifact showcases)
- Balance the 'Dual for Artifact' interaction, can't believe a 40 prowess absolute mountain of a man can lose to a 91 year old granny
- Reduce the amount of random cultural divergences happening, as it gets quite overwhelming
- Generally reduce the spread of random cultures and hybrid cultures everywhere, as it feels as though you can't even hope to have an empire of the same culture anymore.
- Make more options to interact with the new court positions (Jester, Bodyguard, etc.) as currently it's almost always the same random prompts you get.

Overall, I recommend this DLC even at it's price-point. Though, with free update adding in a bunch of the quality content anyway, I can understand why you'd let this one simmer a bit till they update it once more.

I got the dlc as part of the preorder of the royal edition of ck3, i paid 60 euros for the total package. Now they released this single expansion at the price of 30 euros, which makes it the most expensive PDS dlc ever.
