- Trzy nowe zadania dla członków rady - po jednym dla dyplomaty, zarządcy i marszałka. 
- Nowe drzewko spuścizn dynastycznych (Nauka języków, akceptacja i promocja kultury).

Stan techniczny, bugi?
Recenzję piszę 24h po premierze dodatku. 
Na pewno nowa mechanika nie jest kompatybilna ze starymi zapisami.
Jest również problem z wczytywaniem rozgrywki, ale w moim przypadku panaceum okazało się uruchamianie gry i ładowanie sejwa dopiero z menu w grze a nie w kliencie. 

Paradox ogrywał Royal Court na streamach już dwa tygodnie przed premierą. Mieli sporo czasu na polerowanie i testowanie, więc nie spodziewam się jakiś krytycznych bugów - sam żadnych nie doświadczyłem. Jednak wiadomo - co innego setka testerów a co innego milion graczy i różnych konfiguracji...

Moja wczesna opinia: 
Poszukiwanie i pozyskiwanie (wszelkimi możliwymi sposobami) wybitnych osobistości jest teraz kluczowe. Wykucie potężnych artefaktów, pomoc w asymilacji kultur, budowanie prestiżu wśród innych władców - do tego niezbędni są specjaliści. Na tym koncentruje się dodatek i moim zdaniem wyszło to grze na dobre.

109866406.review:
Both an in game and real world moneysink. 

The content in this DLC is good and the features make the game notably more immersive. But it's massively overpriced. 

What you get: 
-The courtroom (where you can look at yourself and your court members as 3D models) + some repeatable events, both as vassal and liege
-The Grandeur mechanic (i.e., how extravagant your court is), which is an extensive moneysink and gives various bonuses the higher you get it
-Minor court positions, again, moneysink with minor bonuses for maintaining them
-Court artefacts (to exhibit in your throne room for bonuses) and personal artefacts (to put in your newly introduced equipment inventory for bonuses) and a couple of different ways of getting them. 

And that's about it. The content is decent but it's nowhere near an amount that would justify charging half the price of a newly released full price game for it. 

Honestly, I was still going to recommend it for those starved for new CK3 content, but the update also introduced a number of bugs (e.g. train commander councilor task not working anymore). Just not really acceptable in its current state. Wait a bit and ideally buy it on sale.

109865383.review:
IT COSTS TOO MUCH

CULTURES
The culture rework is nice: you can create new cultures, combine two into one, and create your regional culture out of already existing one - I like these changes
Each culture has now few traditions, the cultures got divided into groups - for example, Polish, Polabian and Pomeranian are in the Lechitic group. You can now learn other languages.

ARTIFACTS
Now you can hire a person to create an artifact for you - a melee weapon, a chestplate, a crown and many other things.
Or you can just steal them during a war with your neighbour. I've got an artifact that gives me -100% fertility :P
Many of these artifacts increase dynasty renown, prestige, fertility, prowess and other traits.

THE THRONE ROOM/COURT
For me it is a boring, laggy, unnecessary addition - they could've sold it separately... 
The court is only available to emperors or kings, AND you can not be a tribal government :(
You can see people there but they just stand and do nothing more.

ADVISORS
Now you can hire more advisors - the food taster, the jester, the court doctor, bodyguards, the language tutor etc.
It's a pretty cool addition because they are pretty cheap - 0,02 to 0,15 ducats monthly. They provide nice bonuses :)

However, the price for this DLC is too big - it should cost 15$ max. The DLC was overhyped. I would buy it without the court addition if it costed less.

109864665.review:
Every negative review is talking the price. Yes, it is steep. That doesn't mean this is a bad DLC, which can give that impression given the bevy of negative reviews that are *only* about the price. Folks get angry, demand a refund, and then come to this page to lambaste, all the while ignoring the DLC content. Don't let this ridiculous outrage influence your purchasing decisions. If you want this at full price and its features are worth it to you, buy it - otherwise, wait for a sale and enjoy it at a price that makes sense to you. I personally didn't feel like waiting 6 months to get this for $15 less or like I needed to complain about the price tag that *I agreed to pay based on the features they were very transparent would be in this DLC*. But maybe that's just me.

The DLC adds much needed flavor to this game, as well as a reason to actually play a feudal character. Creates an actual court system, adds cultural richness and depth, re-works a lot of the previously static and by-and-large uncontrollable features (cultural dynamics, language, court events, tutoring, assassination) and introduces a very real concept in the medieval world: grandeur. I'm actually having *fun* playing as Alfred of Wessex, for example. The stuff added in this DLC is cool and good, don't let sticker-shocked negative reviews detract from that.

An excellent DLC that enhances the game-play and adds more layers to what is already a fantastic game. It adds several layers that one may not realise on the surface. A lot of work and effort has gone into producing this additional content. I must congratulate the game development team for all their efforts in putting together the Royal Court and game update that was released at the same time as this DLC. It is much appreciated. Whilst there are still a lot that can be added to the game, it was a good place to start after the Northern Lords flavour pack. In my view, Royal Court is well worth the full price for such a feature-rich DLC. 

The enhanced culture system is great as it introduces a dynamic system that allows you to evolve your culture and this makes the game even more enjoyable to play. 109863059.review:
This is one of the few times I have felt compelled to write a review because of the review climate on the page. People are being absolutely ridiculous about this DLC, and I don't think they have any idea how precarious PDX is right now, and how important this expansion was.

I would like to say, my review is that this is a very good expansion. To paraphrase something ProudBavarian said about the expansion, it can completely change the way you interact with the game and leans heavily into roleplaying which is the thing I most appreciate about CK3 as a title in particular. I saw a review that said it was $30 for "minor mechanics" and that is completely unfair-- adding a 3D space with positioned characters to a game where usually you spend 90% of the time staring at a map is a massive departure from form and a very ambitious addition to the game. 

Would it be cool if there were Tribal Courts, or lower level Duke and Count courts? Of course, but there is every expectation that such a thing will be added later, perhaps even in a free update. How could we expect that? By looking at the free culture features which came along with this update. The new culture system is a massive upgrade to the former system, as large in scope as the entire religion system was at release, and everyone got it for free. The one best way to make sure you never get Tribal or Ducal courts is to tell people not to buy this DLC, and not to buy the next flavor pack.

I think if you play CK3 to tell stories and revel in the drama that comes with building your legacy, this expansion is an absolute must-have. If the next expansion is as bold and ambitious as this one, I will be overjoyed.

When I bought the season pass, they had announced they would make fewer but bigger dlc. What we got was half the content of a CK2 dlc for twice the price and the content is overall underwhelming. Probably they had bigger plans which were hindered by the pandemic, but although the dlc turned out a lot smaller, they have to sell it for 30€ now, as they already sold a 30€ dlc through the season pass. 

Visually courts look nice. The lategame would have needed more challenges, decorating a court might be a fun lategame activity, but will it stay motivating longtime?

Languages feel useless, they were better represented by cultures. The language learing decisions could have just targetted French instad of Langue d'Oil.

I do not like the cultural overhaul, it is a step away from hostorical simulation and historical role-playing towards a min-/max-playstyle with stacking boni (what EU4 has become). Instead of +10% income from this building or +5% more of that, I would have prefered things like cultural feasts, events, inheritance laws and other things which increase immersion.

Artifacts are welcome, we had them in CK2, but those equppable 3d models make it the best part of the dlc.

109862204.review:
玩了将近1K小时CK2，神罗天征，科穆宁中兴罗马，最后的波斯人复兴祆教，所罗门统一阿比西尼亚联统拜占庭等等等等，几百年的CK2玩下来是见证了亚欧大陆的百年兴衰与沧海桑田，每次到最后的计分板回顾各位先帝都令我感慨万千。然而玩家能在CK3做什么呢？大体就是4个“er”玩梗吧， 即motherf**ker，granddaughters‘ father，brother slayer 和Pope’s lover.

言归正传，首先，CK3是一个基于4X的RPG游戏，而非基于RPG的4X，现阶段连4X内容都几乎是白板的情况下去增加RPG玩法着实是本末倒置。P社似乎没明白当年CK3首发为什么如此好评，那不是因为他做出了一个多好的游戏，而是CK3让玩家看到了一个好的框架（或者说好白板），等着P社往这个白板里加东西。然而一年半过去了，在游戏性上，除去这次的文化系统更新，宫廷DLC的核心内容可以说没有增加任何的游戏性与深度。
再者，许多在CK2里早已成熟的系统，例如council law，minor title，中华帝国系统，瘟疫系统等等没包括在首发里就罢了，这一年多下来一点影子都没有。在拜占庭和游牧依然是封建制和部落制（是不是下个DLC是后年把拜占庭变成帝国制啊？），波斯以东的文明依然都是一张脸一种衣服的情况下，我很好奇P社做这个DLC是不是只是为玩西欧的玩家服务的？（我没猜错的话现在各种宝物家具之类的也大多都是欧洲风格的吧？）。之前出了个所谓北欧风味包，然后这次更新我一看北欧的宫廷居然和西欧的宫廷是一样的，真的绝了，人家帝国4英法德的建筑都不一样呢，我这风味包就只有几件衣服和事件，连特色宫廷建模都没？
最后，你出这种DLC是想增加玩家的RPG代入感和视觉效果吧，然而就原版那几套衣服和脸型，我只能呵呵，现在谁还不开一大堆服装mod来让世界各地的人民穿得不那么一样一点，合着就摆烂等mod填是吧？说到视觉效果，大多数角色的宫廷开局就是空的，没有任何宝物和家具，合着刚装修好？宫廷就一间大厅没有其他任何房间或者城堡外观，连随意移动镜头和缩放都做不到。再顺带一提，CK2里宫廷经常是人满为患还得玩家往外赶人，而CK3大部分角色甚至皇帝的宫廷就那么几个人，一大半还都是自己的亲戚，请别人还很难请来，就这还宫廷呢，私宅还差不多。

总而言之，单看这个DLC只能说乏善可陈，也没那么烂，然而，结合一年半的开发时间，以及CK3现阶段白板的状态，我实在不认为现阶段出这种DLC能提升多少游戏体验，这种视觉增强和RPG增强的DLC应当放在游戏的后期，策略玩法已经成熟的时候再做（比如现在的CK2），而不是作为第一个DLC。想体验历史兴衰的朋友们还是回去玩CK2吧，至少几百年间每年都能作为开局时间呢，CK3本质上就是只有两个开局的继承，内战，继承，内战外加地图涂色的白板，并且西欧文明外的大部分文明几乎没有多少可玩性可言

109861177.review:
Mechanically, I am satisfied with the content. The artifact and the court systems, as well as the improved cultures, add much needed depth to the otherwise bland base game. The culture aspect is especially enjoyable with its wide variety of choices as well as providing an outlet for prestige that previously tended to build-up when playing feudal rulers. What is disappointing is the implementation of the court mechanic for feudal governments only. While "tribal" governments may not have historically held court in the same way it is portrayed in this DLC, there are plenty of historic analogues that could utilize this mechanic existing within what is CK3's current gross over-generalization of tribal/nomadic peoples in game. This fact is ironically contrasted with Paradox's own sponsored YouTube content leading up to the DLC's release, specifically those videos exploring historical Mongol court protocol. I hope to see this remedied in the future.

Additionally, the use of 3D models in Royal Court is a departure from previous content and the developer's aims feel misguided when considering what the majority of the community is looking to get out of this game. It seems likely that this decision soaked up much development resources leading to the aforementioned lack-luster and even partially implemented court mechanic., This is not to mention the the price tag, which is at least twice what you should be paying for DLC. If you'd like to play Royal Court, I would recommend waiting for a sale.

EDIT: Upon playing the DLC further, it seems like the artifact and, primarily, court interactions are somewhat superficial. Regardless, I am still pleased with the culture systems but at this point it may as well have been one of the smaller $5 content packs.

109861151.review: A bit overpriced, I agree, but I think its price is mostly justified: this expansion brings a whole new dimension to the game and connects to the other systems in quite an organic way, vastly improving its immersion aspect. While I would have appreciated a bit more in terms of contents, especially in terms of courts themes (only 4 at launch) and a visual feedback of amenities improvements, courts appear to be a solid foundations for modding and (alas) future DLCs.

109860287.review:
i had an event where 'an ally gets usurped by a rival and then you can invite that ally to serve in your court with a nickname "footstool" ' happened 3 times in a row... out of 4 times i held court... and the last time it happened, it was my wife's holding that got usurped by our infant son. As "amusing" as it was, it broke what little immersion i had. After that i turned the game off, it is clear that nobody ever tested this garbage. This event should be programmed as an extremely rare, not happen almost every single time you utilize the game's key mechanic. Also the way its implemented doesnt make any sense, it shouldnt be coded this way, when it just selects random charaters to usurp holdings, it makes zero sense for holdings of the queen to be usurped by a baby. One very impatient baby, considering it was going to inherent them anyway.

EDIT: After glossing over other reviews, I've decided to chime in with my opinion about the price matter and overall quality of this DLC. 
Look guys, when they're selling you the DLC that breaks graphics and adds a ton of bugs which they never bothered to test over a year while this "expansion" was in development, at this point you're basically doing their job for them and testing their product. So no, you shouldnt pay $30 for an opportunity to participate in the beta-test. They're the ones who should pay you. 

Also, what ppl in the positive reviews are calling "new mechanics" are really just new buttons you can press to get flat modifiers, like pay 100 gold to the artisan - get a legendary sword that adds 1 prowess (which is like nothing). Also you get to create hybrid-cultures, hooray! Its exactly like creating religions in the base game, only duller. Wow, so much innovation, this gameplay is fire.

Conclusion: do not buy, not even on sale. Even if they fix all the bugs, which they wont, its still a bad dlc that doesnt really add anything new to the game. Promo screenshots were just lie, you never have interesting feasts in your court or anything like that.

After all, why did people like previous installments of this franchize? Because of the storytelling and because of the interesting events. In this game you see basically all the events this game has in the first 3 hours you play, so it was obvious, for me anyway, that the first DLC desperately needed to add some storytelling content. But all you really get is a hall with broken lighting and frozen statues with ugly facial features, because this DLC also decided to downgrade the graphics, on top of adding a bunch of bugs. It doesnt add what it needed to add for this game, game is still just a boring map painting simulator. What little events it has are at best poorly thought out and at worst are immersion-breaking. Nothing worse that a game can be other than being boring.

dear paradox, if you want your games better received: hire new writers and hire at least some testers, i know you think you got an army of unpaid shills to do that, but actually you do pay, not with money, but with your reputation. Also get a new product manager, from the premise to execution this DLC screams of the lack of coherent vision of what this game wants to be. I am sorry to say this, but youre not a small family company anymore.

109859994.review:
You know how Paradox said they were focusing on larger DLCs for CK3, so we'd excuse the long wait time and higher price? This feels very much like a normal $20 DLC that should have come out 3 months ago. Of the 1.5.0 features, I was more excited for the free customizable banners than any paid feature. In addition, the lack of free camera in the court, and limiting it to kings and emperors were two of the first things I changed with mods. The base game is fantastic and made even better with the free features in 1.5.0, and this DLC is a step down by comparison.

That being said, Royal Court marks a decisive turn away from min-maxing and towards immersive role-play, and this is the first time I've ever lost track of time playing CK3. In a way, this DLC is almost necessary towards this role-play vision, even if the features are rather limited. I highly encourage Paradox to continue down this path with future expansions.

Overall I'd highly suggest waiting for a $10-$15 sale a year or two from now. However I firmly believe that you should still plan on getting it as some point if you like the role-playing side of CK3. One could reasonably argue that this DLC is greater than the sum of its parts for what it does to immersion and role-play.

109859800.review:
TLDR: It took about a year for them to release a 3D room which adds nothing to the gameplay.

Longer review, CK3 has had significant issues in terms of gameplay and interaction since it's creation. This doesnt address any of them. Want something new to do between 880-1200? Nah, nothing new exists. You'll still be expanding, dealing with the AI trying to jump you, and endless, endless succession problems. 

Grandure is a few button clicks to handle, new minor positions have little impact on your court, you still have to take time combing through endless generic NPCs with sub par stats trying to force themselves in positions they dont deserve and pissing them off has little consequences. 

The good feature, designing your own coat of arms, is free.

The events from holding court range from, terrible, to "recycled events that were moved into the court". On a positive though the "Get a cat" event seems to repeat pretty often so it's more common to get a cat instead of once a playthrough. 

Byz is still stupidly stable, the abbasids still collapse near endlessly, the AI still cannot assist in combat. None of the combat improvements or AI automation from imperator are in the game.

109859770.review:
I have so much contempt for this "expansion". We were told that CK3 was this highly efficient and modular platform that was going to get barrels of content. In the same time frame that CK2 was out, we had received new religions, new governments, buckets of content and entirely fresh systems. Sure, the DLC model was parasitic then, but at least we were getting *something*. This is just... beyond the pale.

Thirty bucks gets you a 3D court room bauble that looks stiff and lifeless, adds nothing to the game other than being a gold sink for passive bonuses, and includes court positions that we mostly already had in CK2. Relics and artifacts? Already in CK2 as well, and honestly far less intrusive. Enjoy finding exciting relics that grant you tiny opinion boosts or +2 prowess and then having to pay tons of gold to some asshole so they don't degrade. Culture hybridization is just another set of rules like religion, but less enticing. The new culture system feels like something that could have been designed in a week. Add a flimsy window for adding cultural tenets or tendencies or whatever the fuck they are called, a couple decisions, and a new advisor job, and done. I guess some players will make meme cultures like Norse-Turkish and call the expansion great, but once you've messed with the culture system once or twice, there's not much more to see. It's shallow. The moment to moment experience of the game is relatively unchanged. Religions are still all the same, no new governments (which we knew going in, obviously, but still), and you'll still be going through the same twenty or so event chains until you beg for death. Only now you'll occasionally be checking in on the incredibly ugly and for many people laggy court room, because you have to spend your excess gold on something, even if it's just really boring passive bonuses.

It is profoundly offensive to offer this DLC for 30 USD when I've seen modders do much more with less time and fewer resources for free. The amount of content on offer here is like, maybe ten dollars worth, and even then I'd still regret buying it when mods will do more for free. This wraps up all of the content you get for the royal edition, and I'll admit I'm a total rube and part of the problem for purchasing that edition of the game. I haven't pre-ordered anything in years, and I made an exception for Crusader Kings because the second game is just that special to me. Do not under any circumstances buy this expansion for full price. You're not missing anything.

109858628.review:
Whilst the cultural adjustments were a fine addition to the game - even if some of the tenets for particular cultures feel a bit off - and the mechanics surrounding the cultural hybridization are fun and can lead to a more varied game, they feel rather shallow. The fact they came free is a decent bandaid, the paid mechanics are not. The artifact system and the RPG-esque equipping system look good, but the artifacts themselves are less impressive and feel less earned than artifacts acquired in the predecessor. They give marginal bonuses and due to the sheer quantity of them you acquire, there's no sentiment or real incentive to keep a hold of them. In CK2 if you gained or lost an artifact, it felt good due to the RNG aspect of it or especially bad since there was no easy way to get it back once it was taken from you. In CK3, you can see plainly the purpose of the artifact system: a money sink. It's something for a player who inevitably snowballed due to the easiness of the game to spend money on once they became too big to collapse. The same goes for the court system. Whilst it gives you means to help tidy up your realm and become stronger thanks to some of the milestones for achieving certain levels of grandeur, it's something you're not really involved in beyond spending a pittance per month to increase the quality of clothing and food - which, by the way, gives no visual improvement to the courtroom itself - and after some years in-game, you gain some modifier bonuses to your realm. That's it. The court system feels isolated from the rest of the game in a way, and that probably gives some insight into how future DLCs will function. For example, you gain nothing by having the prior flavor pack, since the Norse don't get any unique visuals for their court once you achieve kingdom rank. Also, locking it to kingdom rank and above guts any potential for competing with your own liege for a grander court, which could have delegitimized them in the eyes of their subjects and given you a claim on their title. The game is lacking in little touches like that all throughout, and this new DLC only added a handful of events to give more life to your game.

I wouldn't recommend purchasing this, even if it was 10 dollars cheaper. The game only feels marginally less empty without it.

109858620.review: It would be a nice addition, but it only adds about $5 worth of content

109858584.review:
О жемчужине - тронный зал. Самая бесполезная вещь, что я видел. Это касается именно оформления, все новые механики, с прошениями и прочим спокойно можно было уложить в старый формат таблиц. Сами по себе они просто немного добавляют разнообразия, но честно говоря зачастую того не стоят. 
Но вся суть именно в оформлении, которое выглядит хуже каких-то копеечных симуляторов. Все что вы получаете это вид издалека на пластмассовые мыльные фигурки, смотрящие в пустоту стеклянными глазами.
И видимо все время разработки и цена обуславливается вот этой ересью. Для нее же перелопатили внешность всех других персонажей, которые и в обычных разделах теперь стали мыльными, даже на максимальных настройках и почему-то, да, узкоглазыми. Я действительно не знаю зачем это добавлять. В самой игре нельзя даже настроить вид этого зала, максимум в фоторежиме, ради которого все и было видимо. Потому что игре это не приносит ничего, все, кроме горстки новых, решения и взаимодействия проходят без использования этих технологий. Поэтому да, все было ради скриншота с мыльными пластмассовыми модельками.

Единственное как по мне полезное нововведение, это небольшой ребаланс других стран, введение настройки их устойчивости. 
Добавили механику культур, довольно интересно, но сыровато. Языки, терпимость и прочее неплохо, но большинство традиций косметические, ибо дают кучу слабых размазанных на эпохи, эффектов. Плюс поломали механику культурного идеолога багом, надеюсь поправят.
В целом много мелких багов, вроде пропавших описаний, корявых звуков, имен и прочего.
Предметы приятная вещь, хотя опять же, вот если говорить о формате дополнения, то это же ерундовая вещь, она должна была или сразу быть в игре, или выйти гораздо раньше. 

Уж шутка ли, но тема как с поправками). Напихали в одно дополнение самые разные вещи, можно было б выбирать спокойно убрал бы тронный зал и оставил все остальное. Но тогда и заплатил бы меньше, а это уже никак неприемлемо.

109858579.review:
I have now tried this DLC for quite a few hours.
I'm sad to say, that i really can't recommend this DLC, when it cost 30 euros. Price sets expectations, and this really shouldn't cost more than 10 euros at the maximum no matter how i see it.

I have over the years bought pretty much every single Paradox DLC on day one, but over the last few years i just keep getting disappointed. They release half baked DLC with barely any features, and still demand 20-30 euros for them. I really can't support this anymore, since i no longer see an actual value in it, and would rather just keep playing on the previous versions to avoid any mishaps the new DLC and update brings.

The features of this DLC(and update) are the cultures and court.
Lets start with the court.

It's an extremely barebone 3D court that just gives you a few events and a few spaces to put down some artifacts, that gives a few modifiers. That's basicly it. The court is really ugly and seems like no effort has been put into it, which is a huge disappointment for a main feature of a 30 euro DLC. You get new court positions... that are just more modifiers, and hf appointing people to them whenever the old ones they were assigned to, dies or are otherwise indisposed.
The artifacts are just modifiers that are honestly really boring. Again it feels like no effort has been put into it.

The cultures seem more interesting. I always like to have options to personalise things in games, and this seems to add a bit to it. The feature seems fine for now, but it's a minor thing that doesn't change much. I like the addition of languages, since they add a little flavour to the game. Honestly can't say much more about it, besides it being a little like making your own religion.

So in the end i can't recommend this, unless you get it on a large discount. I'm sad to see this as the first expansion, since it feels like theres so much they can focus on in the game, to improve it so we can keep enjoying it. But this expansion is just a hollow sideshow that doesn't actually improve on the actual game, but is way more of a minigame inside a game.

109857205.review:
I think Crusader Kings III is a strong foundation to build on - we've just been waiting a LONG time to see construction finished. Ultimately, I think the Royal Court makes for a successful "first step" into what will probably be like a decade of expansions.

The court stuff really does add a lot - it's not going to completely change your games, and I imagine the events are going to get repetitive, but as something to fiddle with and play around with during the downtime between expansion it's awesome. Snappy interface, and seeing your growing cast of characters all interacting adds more than you would think. Big fan of how they've implemented court positions as well - the two together make for a good moneysink and a nice way to flesh out that big cluster of courtiers you never remember anything about. Particularly women - I found in male-dominated regions, outside of spymaster and court physician, there was never anything to do with your skilled female courtiers, and this solves that problem nicely.

Artifacts are fun, and at least where I am it's not cheap or easy to farm them - in my first run, even after a century I'm only at 50% capacity, and a lot of the items I have gotten are kinda junk. Cultures seem interesting, but it's expensive to diverge, so I haven't messed around with them yet. Have seen some real-world cultures pop up - Tunisian and Kazakh, maybe some others - which is cool. Definitely gives regions an interesting flavor, without railroading things too hard. Tough line to walk but it seems successful.

All in all, I do think it lives up to the hype - its new systems feel appropriately big and transformative, not just window dressing. I just hope they have the pipeline up and running, because what we have is great, but we're gonna need more of it before it starts to get old again.

One of the best DLC's paradox has ever released. The amount of things this changes is outstanding and while it took a long time to get released it was definitely worth the wait. 3D Court was something I never thought I would see in a Paradox game and it blows my mind that were hear today.  

Those who are saying that this is just minor DLC don't know what they are talking about, this doesn't just add one core mechanic, it effects the entire game in a very deep level by adding Cultures, Languages, and an entire court system that makes the game deeper than ever.  Not to mention that it opens the door to new ways to mod the game that will only make the game that much better. 

The price is a little high, but as someone who has been playing Paradox games since the days of the original Crusader Kings I always see their prices as investments. Unlike most companies that leave their games buggy messes, Paradox games evolves overtime for years and age like a fine wine. (The only exception being maybe Rome since they can't seem to get Rome games right.)

For me, buying DLC has always been with the knowledge that this gives Paradox more money to do more great things cause for the most part this company has yet to fall like so many of my other favourite companies.  That may change one day but for now they still remain one of the best 4X developers out there and I can't wait to see what comes next.

Viele Leute werden es in der Royal Edition mit 'dabei' bekommen haben. Die Royal Edition ist im Internet weiterhin (!)legal(!) verfügbar und kostet dort mittlerweile weniger als das Addon Royal Court an sich. Das zunächst einmal dazu. Zum Addon an und für sich muss ich sagen, dass ich das Spiel auf Englisch spiele, mir deshalb noch keine Übersetzungsfehler aufgefallen sind, natürlich. Das wäre aber auch das allerletzte, was ich einem Spiel als Fehler ankreiden würde. Man muss leider sagen, Übersetzungen stehen natürlich ganz weit unten auf der Prioritätsliste. 

Ich will auch nicht darauf eingehen, was die neuen Features sind, da die bei diversen Presseorganen und Paradox selbst hinreichend erklärt wurden. Ich muss allerdings meine Enttäuschung zur Kenntnis geben, dass das Addon so veröffentlich wurde. Heruntergebrochen würde ich sagen, gibt es 3 Säulen des Addons: 1. Artefacte, die ganz nett sein können, da sie diverse Boni bieten und u.a. auch Kriegsgründe liefern können, 2. der Thronsaal, ein 3D Raum, wo im Moment noch nicht wirklich viel Action ist und 3. Sprachen und Kulturen verändern, was man aber sich auch erst einmal leisten können muss, wenn man bedenkt, dass selbst kleine Änderungen (1 Slot) min. 3000 bis 4000 Prestige kosten. 

Als Fazit muss ich leider sagen, dass ich 30 Euro für das Addon als deutlich zu viel ansehe. Ich bin froh, seinerzeit die Royal Edition gekauft zu haben, ich wüßte nicht, ob ich Royal Court nicht wieder retounieren würde, wenn ich es mir hier so gekauft hätte. Vom Preis Leistungsverhältnis würde ich es eher bei ca. 15 Euro veranschlagen, 20 höchstens, wenn man sehr wohlwollend für den Entwickler und angesichts der Inflation etc, sein möchte. Aber 30 Euro sind definitiv zu hoch gegriffen. Das Addon ist die 30 Euro so nicht wert, muss ich leider sagen.

109852752.review:
Royal Court so far is a 7/10. It is acceptable. I were not disappointed since I had low expectations. For people with Royal Edition, is Royal Court worth 30 euro? No. 20 euro? No. 15 euro? Yes. In other words wait for sale.

I have seen people comparing this to Witcher 3 Blood & Wine DLC price. Royal Court doesn't justify the price, unlike Blood & Wine; that is just the sad reality.

However, I recommend Royal Court to roleplaying enthusiasts who love to have a throne room, upgrade the amenities of your court and appoint courtiers and nobles to prestigious positions of your court. Don't expect it to be "the Sims" in the middle ages. You can't pick the wallpaper color or carpet, but you can display banners, furs and artifacts you have gotten through looting or crafting.

Holding court is done through events; you still choose between different answers to interact with your vassals and courtiers. There are no 3D models moving up to you and bowing, kneeling or kowtowing, if that is what you were hoping for. 

Most of the new events come from holding court or interacting with your liege's court. I have only done one playthrough, so I can't say if there are many new events for outside of holding court.

At the time of this review; equipping gear on yourself doesn't show on your 3D model, it just gives stat boosts to yourself (weapons give prowess), prestige and renown.

I can see this being fun the first few playthroughs, but it will get stale pretty fast once you have discovered all the mechanics. 

Culture mechanics has gotten an upgrade. You can now customize your culture in several different ways: You can create a hybrid culture or diverge from the original culture. Paradox has given us a lot of options to tweak our culture with different traditions, heritage and cultural pillars. There are too many to list, but last I counted there were at least 30+ different culture traditions you can customize your culture with. You can, for example, create a warrior culture, spiritual culture, bureaucratic culture or meritocracy. Or mix the many different traditions into one crazy culture.

Conclusion: Steer away from Royal Court if you are not a roleplayer. Even if you are one, don't buy it until it has at least 50% discount. For those who got the cash to burn and are roleplayers: It is decent. Not bad, not great.

109851957.review: I had higher hopes for this Expansion than perhaps I should have.  I was hoping for more immersion based on the developer's portrayal of the content.  As it is the "fully immersive throne room" is barren even with enhancement, is too generic, and serves as nothing more than a secondary UI for what already occurred (and still does occur) in separate game windows.  The characters don't do anything but stand around.  There is no way to move around the room, and if you click on the characters, you just get the usual pop up window about them.  The most of the other enhancements of the DLC feel minor and do not justify the price of the DLC.  This is a disappointing first effort for an expansion of what could be a great game, and if this is a sign of future expansions, it may be the last one I purchase.

109850482.review:
This is PDX’s most expensive single DLC. I have all DLC for several other PDX games and I can say without a doubt that for costing 1.5x, 2x, or even 3x as much as some other DLC, this does not provide nearly enough content to justify the price. Given how long it took PDX to make this relative to other DLCs, I could understand the price if they put A LOT more content in it, and it quite surprises me that they didn’t, given the development length. It is not a game-compromising expansion (wink wink Leviathan) and the stuff that it has is quite good. Buy it at a 50% sale. I think that given all of the facts, this game’s dev team is getting the short end of the stick, and I regret my role in supporting that, especially when this game has such potential. Please prove me wrong PDX.  I think, in the future, I might just save my money and finally get all CK2 DLC.

TL:DR get at half price

(Second Supplement: What you really get)

1) You get a Royal Court Room (from kingdom rank upwards, if you are feudal), for storing Artifacts, and sinking some money in grandeur to get some bonuses or multiplier for them. This is not really adjustable and immersion breaking. If you are holding court, you need to stop game, because outside things still happen, even pop ups can occure and you can't proper handle them.

2) You can individualisze your culture ingame. This can also give you some decent bonuses. Some cultures already have good bonuses, so you can simply switch your culture and then there isn't that big of a need for creating your own. PDX lets you sniff on what you don't have in the free version. But you won't miss the mixing or creation of an own culture, because it is an idea, good for a game like Imperator Rome (maybe they had the idea there and because of stopping development they added it in CK3, because the DLC itself is really scarce even with this "feature".

3) You get some court jobs more than the free version.

This DLC is frustration and is following PDX new tradition of bad DLCs.

109848448.review:
Here's how I'd sum this up -
This DLC adds a lot - Royal Courts for vassals, kings, and emperors, which themselves are a very interesting element of both gameplay and especially immersion. CK2 was a wonderful game but it was hard to ever see my character as a living, breathing person. Royal Court adding the ability to see them in an actual space was wonderful.

The return of Artifacts is wonderful, especially with the new interface for slotting them in. It's a thousand times easier to see what you have equipped and what it does now than in CK2, a real masterclass in how to take a base feature everyone liked and make it even better in a sequel. The combination of Royal Courts and Artifacts also makes for some of the most gorgeous things in the game, the Court Artifacts are splendorous things - wonderful tapestries, excellently-designed boxes that bleed a living medieval feeling, that communicate the life and vivacity of the period.

On top of that, the biggest thing that EVERYONE interacts with is the cultural revamp - culture was already a fairly interesting and new thing compared to the nothingness it was in CK2, but now every culture is encouraged to play differently - a Dutch player will focus on making money, Saxons on conquest, et cetera et cetera. What's more, if you want to revamp your base culture, hybridization lets you put together the best of both cultures, so that instead of a genocidal maniac, you might actually play like a decent monarch (Though be honest, most of the playerbase will still probably wipe out the other cultures.) 

Of course, the main downside is the pricetag. $30 is a hell of a lot for a DLC, even one this major. I could even see $25 at a stretch, but $30 is putting the toe across the line. I'm recommending the game based mostly on the actual content- it makes picking this up definitely worthwhile, but if you don't have a lot of cash to burn, wait for a sale.

No, I haven't played the expansion yet. And certainly not enough to be able to give it a fair judgment, less than 24h after release.

What I CAN judge though, are the hilarious "reviewers", with their bitter tears about pricing. 

Nobody forces you to buy DLC. Nobody forces you to buy DLC day one, for the full price.

Reviews exist to give people an idea if the sold content is good. Everyone can see the price and make an independent decision if they can afford it or if it's worth it to them. Nobody gains anything of value by wading through your tirades.

And if you think that your tears will make Paradox change their mind about pricing, no it won't. 

But these people seem to love their opportunity to moan once again way too much, passing on the actually effective alternative of voting with their wallet. 

Ultimately it means that Paradox can safely ignore all of them. There is no actually valuable feedback and the revenue will probably skyrocket.

109847163.review:
Royal court is a amazing expansion that is slightly ovepriced. The new features they have added to the game really enrich the experience. The new culture system revamps what felt like a outdated system when compared to the religious one. Cultures really do feel unique rather than just the technological difference from before now certain tenets of a culture grant stat bonuses,events and even languages which you can learn to make other cultures like you a bit more. Hybridizing with new cultures and diverging feels rewarding and really adds to the roleplaying and storytelling potential of the game. This is easily the best feature of this DLC.

The new court is great from both a artistic and gameplay perspective it gives a ton more content when playing as both a vassal and a liege. You can now directly petition your liege for things and have your vassals do the same to you. This really improves the roleplay in the game, pulling the player out of the map screen and into the 3D court room makes these interactions feel far more personal. I actually tend to remember these and when a certain vassal consistently annoys me or when my liege refuses my requests it makes you want to screw them over when the opportunity arises.

The only major issue with the DLC is the price. There is a ton of content here and it's content that will impact your game regardless of where you play on the map (unlike the single culture focused flavor packs) and it's far bigger than any of the individual expansions for CK2 were, but even then the 30 dollar price tag really is a bit steep and it stains a otherwise perfect expansion, however I would still recommend it because I truly do think it's still worth money due to the huge improvement on the game that it makes. I sincerely hope paradox reconsiders it a bit as compared to the really well priced flavour packs this feels a bit over priced I really think these expansions should be $20 instead or at least $25

109846372.review:
Is it a fun addition to the game? Yes
Is it worth 30€? Idk, not in my opinion.

But if you like CK3 and want more detailed gameplay this dlc works for you. 
Get back your personal inventory, order people to forge swords, shileds, armor etc to boost your strenght in combat. And i must say the bonuses of the artifacts in the court room are insanly OP sometimes.

But enough with items, Holding Court is a fun experience of being a king/emperor, bring 2-3 people to  a hearing infront of you, solve issues and grant them aid, or yeah do whatever you want with them. Every decision you make will influence relations and your court "value points".

Court appointments are interesting as well. You can now assign people like "Cup bearer", Body Guard, Court Jester, Food Tester etc but beware. Most of the roles have heavy scheme influence on you if they turn, like the food tester, cup bearer and other close appointments.
They all give good prestige, piety etc bonuses but ofcourse cost upkeep between 0.1-1 gold.

I would personally wait for a sale, or support the devs now and pay full price, your choice.
This is my opinion about the game and everyone has their own experience.

Kann man dieses DLC empfehlen??
Ja und Nein.
Zuerst mal das Ja 
Die Kulturen Verbindung gut und diese gab es ja früher um Fortschritt zu bekommen, allerdings hätte ich mir in Kulturverbindung dann mehr auf den Nordmannen oder aus dem Moslembereich genommen, da mit diesen doch sehr viel Kontakt besteht.
Die religiöse Verbindung kann man oder muss man noch mit rein nehmen damit die katholische Kirche noch stärker werden kann, da iwr ja alle wissen, dass die Kirche Eigenschaften von anderen Religionen geklaut haben und dann den anderen christlichen Glauben zerstört hat.
Das Wappen selber herzustellen macht schon Spaß nur hätte ich dann sehr gerne aber dann ohne Voreinstellungen gearbeitet und selber Wappen erschaffen.
Ist ja schön und gut, aber so bin ich doch nicht frei, wenn ich zuerst ein Wappen nehmen muss um dieses dann zu verändern.

So zu den Neins
Nach mehreren Stunden des Spiels, zuerst als Graf, finde ich den Thronsaal ziemlich nervig nach einer gewissen Zeit und dieses 3D passt einfach nicht dazu.
Für mich wäre es schöner ein Bild des Thronsaales und dann so die Artefakte zur Ausstellung bringen, genauso wie als man persönlich die Artefakte und Rüstungen trägt.
Zum anderen das Huldigen seinem König ist auch nervig, aber diese komplett bescheuerte aufploppen der Pedition für ein Amt ist noch mehr nervig, man sollte dies doch so machen, dass man dann selbst anklicken kann ob man ein Ratsposten haben möchte und diese ganze Zeit des zeigen nervt.
Zum anderen ist der Preis von knapp 30 Euro einfach überteuert und nicht angemessen, so zwischen 15 und 20 Euro wäre in Ordnung aber so nein.

Fazit:
Das DLC bringt viel neues nur hoffe ich, dass noch einiges nach gepatcht wird und dass dieser Thronsaal in 3D verschwindet, denn ist man in diesem Thronsaal drinnen sieht man nicht mehr was auf der Karte los ist.
Kaufempfehlung schon nur es muss halt jeder selber wissen ob er jetzt das DLC kauft oder später wenn dieses billiger ist.
Ich für mich als CK3 Fan stand nie außer Frage, dass ich mir den DLC hole.
Und daher zum Schluss müsste ich meinen Daumen eigentlich in die waagrechte bringen geht aber leider nicht und deswegen ist für mich das DLC AUSGEGLICHEN in der Bewertung

109845501.review:
Ich würde mit dem Preis/Leistungs-Verhältnis nicht so hart ins Gericht gehen, wie es viele hier tun. 

Ja es gibt noch einige Übersetzungsfehler, leere Platzhalter und einige TODOs der Entwickler sind auch noch hier und da hinterlassen. Diese finde ich aber nicht so drastisch als würden sie das Spiel nicht spielbar machen. Und bei so vielen Sprachen und vor allem einem so textlastigen Spiel kommen Fehler nun mal vor. Ja, man könnte mehr in die Qualitätssicherung investieren und ich hoffe, dass Spieler aber auch so fair sind und diese Fehler auch melden und diese dann gefixt werden, anstatt sich nur darüber auszulassen.

Zum Thema Preis/Leistung kann ich auch verstehen wenn viele sagen, dass es die 30€ nicht Wert sind. Der neu hinzugekommene Content mag für die Zeit und das Geld was darein gesteckt wurde tatsächlich nicht verhältnismäßig wirken, man muss aber bedenken, dass nicht nur neuer Content hinzugekommen ist , sondern dieser auch in bestehender Logik berücksichtigt und implementiert werden muss. Kulturen, Sprachen, Artefakte, die neuen Hofämter usw. muss komplett ineinandergreifend auch im bestehenden Spiel eingebaut werden. Hierbei alle Eventualitäten die auftreten könnten zu testen und zu prüfen ist schon eine Mammutarbeit und ich finde für den Zustand in welchem sich das Spiel jetzt befindet, finde ich es nach wie vor beachtlich.

Fazit:
Ja, es hätte vielleicht mehr Qualitätssicherung betrieben werden können..
Ja, der neue Content scheint nicht im Verhältnis zum Preis zu liegen...
Ja, es gibt noch Bugs und Übersetzungsfehler..

ABER..

Meiner Meinung nach ist der Preis gerechtfertigt, da neuer Content auch in bestehender Logik implementiert werden und berücksichtigt werden muss UND das Ganze in allen Sprachen zu testen UND auch noch alle Eventualitäten zu prüfen... 
Hut ab, totally worth it!

109845295.review:
This is a good dlc. Not the best obviously. But the main issue is; IS IT AN EXPANSION?

Let's be honest, we have been waiting for an expansion for 16 months(give or take). What we end up is, kind of a flavor pack, which would be good a polish for a finished game. CK3 lacks content and playstyle varieties, which this dlc can't compete with. This dlc would only suit if it came up for CK2. Getting a new duel system is kind of an equal, what this DLC brings. It feels like a mere patch.

+ Court design and events are nice to get occupied
- Events are repetitive( had the same events in 2 hours of gameplay)
+ Artifacts are nice
- You spent 50 gold to get them, which is odd(easily affordable)
- You get new objectives for council members WITH A DLC. It is really weird to include this in DLC.
+ Learning new languages, diverging cultures or hybridizing them, are kind of an occupation you ask for during your 5x game.

I give a thumbs up for this DLC being good. But this isn't the dlc we needed.

It's not bad at all but the content on offer for the price tag is rather absurd. 30 euros for something that feels more like 15  euros worth of content really.

I'm glad i got this as part of the Royal Edition on GMG back at release, where the whole game was just about 45 euros with the 3 future DLCs bundled in, otherwise I'd feel more bitter about this first "major" expansion for CK3 if i paid more.

It brings back the inventory system and artifacts which is nice to see again and now there's a 3D court you get to see and even fill with things you earned, minor titles are also back and more interesting and fleshed out unlike in CK2 where all they did was just get you 10+ opinion for a character and there's also the culture stuff that was expanded which is cool  but the culture stuff hasn't been all that super exciting for me personally, mainly what happens now is you end up forming mega hybrid cultures that just gets more and more out of hand as you play.

Overall it's just kinda lack luster for the asking price, like the content it self is not bad at all, in fact it's good but the price is awfully high for the amount of content it contains. 
Don't pay 30 for it, but when it's 50% off and drops to 15 then id easily recommend it.

109842754.review:
Price vs Content in this dlc is not worth it at all! ( that alone is a do not recommend )  It's $42.95 in AUD 

Review for the actual content. 

The court system,
All the court system is gameplay wise, is a money sink to get extra prestige and renown with some random events thrown in. Why is it a money sink? with the new court you have to spend upkeep to up the grandeur of your court, if your court is below the grandeur of other courts around you, you lose ticking prestige, the upkeep isn't to expensive but early game it will chunk your money a decent bit. 

The inventory and equipment that I've seen so far is mostly just more extra prestige, renown and prowess aka mostly stats that don't matter really. 

Now you're sitting here like that actually sounds pretty good if you wanted to do a tribal run, well NOPE tribals don't get courts so I guess F tribals. You do still get inventory / equipment though so when you do eventually swap to feudal you can spice up your court ( but honestly you should have a court from the get go though ofc smaller) 

Culture Update, Honestly it just boils down for a way to skip innovations as a tribal so you can go feudal faster so you can actually use the court. 
For the most part the culture hybrid is nice to just get rid of shitty traditions for the obviously better ones and if you like hey that just sounds like reforming your faith you'd be 100% correct, that's all there is to it. 

( calling it now there gonna be some youtube video about how OP norse / greek combo is, greek will all the innovations and a bunch of traditions that lower M@A upkeep and norse with their OP M@A yep just gonna steamroll everyone ) 

Honestly the most slept on part ( though I don't believe it's apart of the dlc just the free patch but that is the Coat of Arms designer, you can now design your house, count, duke, kingdom and empire coat of arms at ANY point in the game, you can also change your factions colour which is nice) 


If you read all this and think yeah that's just what I want, just get the game edition that adds the dlc's ( the season pass or royal edition what ever they're calling it, it's much cheaper)

109842722.review:
A little on the pricier side for sure, but the content is really fun and adds a lot to the game. The titular royal court mechanic is very immersive (which is impressive for a GSG) and really adds a layer of depth to the characters within it. The artifact system is a little to generous with the rate at which you can acquire them, but it is far and above better than CK2s. As for the culture rework, PDX have done what base game CK3 did for religion, they have made it so much more than just a name and colour on a map.

I'd recommend it for sure, even at this price if you have the money to spare, but maybe it'll be best to wait for a sale if you think it's too much.

109841659.review:
Ce DLC et la mise à jour qui l'accompagne rafraîchissent considérablement l'expérience en jeu. Il y a de nouvelles musiques, de nouveaux portraits, les visages ont été retravaillés, les cultures aussi, et j'oublie énormément de fonctionnalités, je ne cite que ce qui m'a marqué. Le principe de la Cour Royale est excellent : Quel plaisir de pouvoir enfin, agir en véritable souverain ! Malheureusement, et c'est là une première déception pour moi, la cour Royale n'est disponible que pour les Rois et Empereurs. Je trouve ça dommage, car c'est véritablement une fonctionnalité agréable, et on a pas toujours la possibilité d'être roi ou Empereur dans une partie (Il aurait été sympathique de l'avoir pour les ducs indépendants, style petits royaumes irlandais, et ça aurait été logique. Certains gros ducs, comme le duc de Normandie en France, etc...). Ce qui fait qu'on retombe, en conséquence, dans les boucles de gameplay habituelles de crusader Kings. Autre problème de la cour royale : La répétitivité. J'y ai joué environ 2h30, et je retombe déjà sur les mêmes problèmes lors de mes audiences (J'en ai fait quoi, 3 - 4 ?). C'est dommage, parce qu'à long terme, les audiences vont perdre énormément en intérêt.
Vos vassaux, vos courtisans peuvent venir vous voir pour régler leurs différents, là dessus rien à dire, c'est varié et sympathique. On peut aussi récupérer un territoire de jure par la diplomatie (Quelle Chance !), utile quand on est pas un va en guerre. En ce qui concerne les Artefacts, peut-être suis-je dur, mais je trouve qu'il y a trop de propositions pour en créer. Ce n'est pas assez rare si vous voulez. Le principe des langues que l'on peut apprendre est sympathique, ça rajoute un côté "RP". Mais, petit problème selon moi : On a pas moyen de savoir quelle langue est parlée ou. On peut savoir quelle langue est la langue des courts voisines, mais on ne peut savoir quelle langue est parlée dans les comtés, les duchés... Je trouve ça vraiment dommage, car ça atténue grandement ce sentiment de "Multiculturalité" de nos royaumes et empires, un comble pour une maj qui cherche précisément à nous donner ce sentiment, via la refonte des cultures. 

        Quel est le rapport qualité prix de ce DLC, désormais ? Grande question. Il est indéniable que les développeurs ont beaucoup travaillé dessus. La cour Royale est splendide, c'est une petite révolution et sans doute, est-ce là une raison de son prix. Mais je ne peux m'empêcher de penser que 30 euros, c'est excessif. 30 euros, c'est le prix d'un jeu, voir même plusieurs. Or, ici, pour 30 euros, vous avez accès à d'excellentes fonctionnalités, certes mais des fonctionnalités finalement bien légères et très générales (C'est du mieux un peu ici, un peu là, mais il n'y a pas de véritable transformation du gameplay, la court royale apporte un supplément vraiment bienvenu mais peut-être un peu, disons, léger ?).  La mise à jour gratuite qui accompagne le DLC est superbe, dans l'ensemble on ne peut qu'être satisfait. Mais ça reste cher payé. Je pense que 20 euros aurait été un prix plus correct (20 euros, le prix d'un gros DLC de Stellaris pour ceux qui connaissent...). Je ne peux néanmoins que vous le recommander, car même si je suis très critique envers cette extension j'en suis satisfait. Mais si vous pouvez, attendez les réductions.

EDIT : Les devs on rajouté la court royale pour les gouvernements tribaux ! Cela, sans compter quelques autres ajouts en termes d’événements... Le suivit parait donc correct, pour un DLC satisfaisant sur la durée.

109840776.review:
Bottom line.... What you pay for what you get, is terrible value. Terrible.

I love the game, love the genre and have a ton of hours played in a multitude of games from conquer everything to roleplaying a characters traits and everything in between. Oh the content that is there is great and it adds more events and another layer to the game but, again, the cost of the DLC for what you get is not worth the price tag.

You're spoon fed... 'We're giving you this awesome free patch! With all this stuff.' Reality is that it is a patch. A patch to fix bugs and issues, not free content. It was coming anyway. In fact, if anything, they are making fundamental changes to the game so they can then add content that they can charge for and disguising half of it as a free patch for everyone to make them seem like they're doing you a favour. It and they are really not.

 So after all the great free patch content you get we then move on to the content that you need to pay for in 'Royal Court'. What is there is very welcome and does add another layer to the game but there is simply not enough meat on the bone to justify the price tag. The royal court can only be accessed by Feudal Kingdom and above and whilst that in itself isn't a bad thing and I have no issue with it, there perhaps should be, for the asking price, a lower different option for Pagan's. Maybe a less involved tribal tent or longhouse or something with different options but something to give you the feel of staying in that lane. This is purely based on the asking price and what we were sold.... 'more grander content less frequently.' Royal Court is just lacking that grandness. In spades.

 End of the day, I'm a sucker and have happily paid for the extra things that are there because I love the game and I know I've gotten my value out of what i've paid tenfold but it still doesnt make it right. For the asking price, there should be a lot more to show for it.

Negative review.

109840332.review:
I really have to care about a game to dedicate the time to write a steam review that's more than a couple sentences.

Firstly, CK3 as a base game is still fun and probably the most approachable iteration of ck made thus far. Royal court succeeds in making ck3 more fun to play, but that is where its success ends. Royal court adds very little content and none of it brings any meaningful changes to how you play ck3. Culture sees the most notable improvement and brings some solid RP mechanics, even if it only really manifests as additional opinion modifiers. The new events are much welcome but they don't alter the gameplay loop at all and the same events appear far too frequently, just like when the game launched. Intrigue is simultaneously the most useful character focus while remaining the most frustrating, since it ensures you'll get a notification once a month that some random countess is humping her court bishop, or that your marshal had a random courtier assassinated 20 years before your current character was even born. The court visualizer was a promising feature, but it feels like they dedicated far too many resources to visualize something that could have been portrayed just as well with 2d artwork and some descriptive text. Nothing has been done to address the incompetent AI, but at least I know Kaiser Henry the fourth has a "stinky court."

Speaking on more than just the DLC's additions, ck3 does a very poor job of simulating any government type other than feudal, and even then their feudal government type is applied far too broadly. The expansion introduces no unique administration systems for the ERE or the (non-existent) nomads, nor does it offer a proper iqta or republic rework. Republics remain nonfactors and are still not playable. In my 300+ hours since launch I have not once seen a republic such as venice or pisa attempt to expand their realm. Compared to its most recent predecessor, ck3 still stale and predictable, especially after your first 50-80 years as a ruler. Regardless of your ruleset, the AI is incredibly passive and the only challenge for someone that is familiar with the game's mechanics comes in the form of arbitrary law/succession restrictions that bring no meaningful difficulty and just makes new playthroughs feel like a slog as you wait 200+ years to institute primogeniture. Mongols are still the only plausible challenge you'll face after your first 3-4 rulers, but from my experience they still collapse before stretching beyond the Caspian.

I'm having some fun with my current playthrough, but once I wrap that up, ck2 with HIP will remain my preferred way to play crusader kings.

109840045.review:
Mana was not the disease, it was the symptom.

The sad truth with paradox games lately (over the past 5-6 years) is that they are giving way too much player agency to compensate for a lack of mechanics implemented. For a part of the community, this gives the impression of playing a game in a rather unrealistic dull environment. Yes, CKIII with all its plots, etc. is freaking dull in my opinion. 

The events end to be all the same, there is no big differences playing one culture or another except for a few min-max % modifiers in whatever category you won’t care about, same for religions. You’re spending renown, faith or whatever for reasons you don’t quite understand.

Examples:
-	In this expansion you are given the possibility to diverge your culture. In place of having a compelling dynamic way of seeing cultures emerge and being mixed up together (being dynamically created) it’s in the player power to diverge the culture of a whole country. 
-	Another example: there is no link between the artifacts you have and the possibility to wear it in the barbershop. So, if you want to put your papal tiara on without possessing it well, go ahead. What’s the point of trying to gain those artifacts only for their modifiers?...
-	You can improve the splendor of your court, etc. But for what? Again, a few min-max modifiers? What’s the point? 

By trying to be as sandboxy as possible to please a certain crowd, paradox is losing its way with players that want to play a simulation, where things happen organically. For a certain crowd here, the fun seems to lie in creating weird faiths, playing with nude characters or be as incestuous as possible. I wanted to give another point of view from the part of the community that would like paradox to go back to simulation games, with realistic thriving stories dynamically happening in the game and less player control.

Anyway. Fingers crossed for Vicky III, please don’t mess this one up.

109838837.review:
A DLC tem um conteúdo legalzinho até, mas levou um bom, bom tempo para ser feita, sobre a promessa de que a Paradox iria parar de lançar varias DLCs, o que criou uma quantidade absurda de conteúdo para seus antigos jogos, para tentar focar em grandes DLCs de alta qualidade, com muito mais conteúdo, e que levassem mais tempo para serem feitas.

Essa DLC certamente levou muito tempo para sair, mas o conteúdo não é, em nada, maior que as DLCs antigas de CK2, EU4 e outros jogos mais antigos, certamente não justifica o preço de 60 reais em comparação as demais.

Sobre a DLC, seus focos principais são:
-O sistema de corte, que ignorando a parte inútil do 3D cria novas formas de se gastar dinheiro para obter alguns bonus, e alguns eventos adicionais.
-Um sistema de equipamentos, que já existia no CK2
-Um novo sistema de cultura, onde a mesma tem grandes efeitos nas habilidades de cada personagem, suas tendências, e até valores culturais além dos religiosos.

Apenas a parte da cultura, na minha opinião, adiciona algo de grande relevância para a gameplay, como falei, é legal, é melhor ter a DLC do que não ter a DLC, mas se você não tem pressa compre nas promoções.

原本的DLC策略是70的大拓展包和40的小沉浸包交替推出，维持一年出一个大拓展包和小沉浸包的速度，然而CK3的开发策略变了，大拓展包价格提高，小沉浸包价格降低，结果就是小沉浸包内容不足，而大拓展包的开发周期过长，以至于CK3发售半年才推出第一个北境群雄，北境群雄可玩性尚可但容量真算不上丰富，而这次的大拓展包则又过了近一年才推出。如此漫长的开发周期并没有给游戏带来更深度的玩法，宝物很容易变成数值游戏，宫廷玩上一遍就没什么新意了，真正有趣的更新只有新的文化机制，然而还有一部分包含在免费更新里。可以说本次的大拓展包并没有达到应有的水准（无论是价格还是开发周期），因此如果CK3的依然保持这样的开发策略，我很难对这个游戏接下来的持续更新抱有太多信心。
希望CK3组在接下来的开发中能够提高效率并且在大小DLC的内容上进行调整。

109836351.review: I'm going to chose to skip the usual stuff about every paradox DLC being overpriced and go right and talk about the actual game. Firstly most of the changes, culture expansion, royal court, etc aren't relevant unless your a prominent king or higher and if your someone like me that enjoys starting as a lowly count and building yourself up then it can be pretty fusterating. However it also makes success in your dynasty that much more rewarding. As of the many new extra events they've included so far i haven't seen too many but the ones that i have seen are pretty interesting, i have also only done one play-through as the count of Wien so possibly expanding your religious and cultural differences would help with finding more new events. But as for the good stuff. Once my count finally reached the king of Germany the amount of new things i could do was pretty impressive and you could tell that they spent a lot of work on the 3D models. The new language and cultural dynamics also added an interesting spin to the game especially for someone who tends to enjoy playing in the diplomacy lifestyle. whether you want to wait for a sale to buy it or skip it all together is up to you but for now i have no regrets in my purchase 7/10

109834174.review:
Je pense qu'au vu des réaction suscitées par ce DLC, Paradox aurait mieux fait d'inclure la refonte des cultures et l'apport des artefacts dans le DLC plutôt que de l'offrir en MAJ gratuite. Au moins, le prix aurait été pleinement justifié et les consommateurs auraient compris qu'ils paient aussi, quelque part, pour cette maj qui change beaucoup de choses. C'est une forme de redistribution en somme.

Pour se focaliser sur le DLC en lui-même, celui-ci ajoute quand même pas mal de choses : un grand nombre d'évènements et de possibilités de gameplay pour les rois/empereurs et leurs vassaux. Bien sûr, cela renforce leur pouvoir, mais cela nous renvoie à une certaine réalité (bien que je pense qu'il aurait été préférable de l'étendre aux ducs indépendants). Mais cela apporte avant tout de nouvelles possibilités dans une phase (mid/late game) où le jeu pouvait commencer à s'essouffler et où il ne restait souvent plus qu'à blober ses voisins. Désormais, de nombreuses interactions seront ouvertes et vous devrez répondre aux attentes de vos vassaux.

En somme, vous pourrez estimer que ce DLC n'est pas très intéressant. Mais il pose de nombreuses bases pour l'évolution du gameplay de cet opus et tend à le démarquer de ses prédécesseurs. Définitivement, CK3 ne sera pas un maj graphique de CK2.

This is a tentative yes. After around 12 hours of playing it, I can say that Royal Court definitely adds a much needed breath of fresh air into the game for those who have already gotten bored of vanilla CK3. However, I feel as though this could have and frankly, should have, been released as a free update, or at the very least, less than 30 dollars. 

I personally could no longer play without Royal Court and what it adds. In that way, it's like a drug. Sure, you don't necessarily [i]need[/i] it, but it makes you feel good, and once you try it, you're hooked. Then you need it. 

My advice is that if you want it, or think you need it, you should probably buy it. If you don't think you need it, then don't get it.

以上，我觉得起码不值得90，要是你80买的皇家版那就和我一样，能玩，是新东西，但是没啥诚意。

Артефакты значительно лучше выглядели во 2-й части, теперь несколько дешевых картинок, дублирующих друг друга, уровня мобильной поделки, похоже из какой-то бесплатной библиотеки, плюс куча багов, особенно радуют вылеты без сохранения и откатом на несколько лет, это если еще загрузится. People are complaining about this DLC - I find their complaints to be largely unjustified. 

I have only played using this DLC for a couple hours but found that it massively improved playability. The 3D court room, artifact system, and other mechanics make this game more involved to an incredible degree. It may have taken Paradox longer to develop, but thus far I have found it to be well worth the wait, especially within the framework of remote development due to COVID. I paid full price for the game and full price for this DLC and have no complaints, if Paradox maintains this level of detail I will continue to be pleased with the latest installment of Crusader Kings. For maximum involvement, I recommend playing a Viking culture with this DLC, utilizing both Northern Lords and Royal Courts for maximum enjoyment.

可以肯定的是，今年是漫长而有趣的一年，我们在这里一直等待着值得的产品。
Royal Court不仅是CK3的第一个扩展项目，而且还将提出一套对CK3系列来说全新的功能，包括文化进化和语言。这在很大程度上是一个新的突破。
考虑到这一点，目前我们对在steam上对Royal Court给出好评的进展并不完全满意，尤其是在内容丰富度方面。我们确实需要解决一些问题再给出好评，并正在花更多时间确保它符合你对我们的期望标准。
我们也理解延迟给好评造成的挫折，但我们希望确保我们总是尽可能地坦诚相待，让你直接听到我们的消息。这是一种棘手的平衡，一方面是 "只要我们完成了确保它的准备工作，它就会发布"，另一方面是在我们确实需要时间来审查和做出这些改变时，才给出确切的时间表，但却对时间表做出必要的、令人不安的改变。
既然如此，你可以期待关于2023年好评发布日期的消息。我们所有的玩家都在努力跟随他们的项目完成，并确保他们开始的所有任务得到充分实现和支持。这意味着他们将继续努力工作，确保你得到你期望的好评。
我们超级感谢你们对《十字军之王III》所表现出的所有奉献和热情。你们对Royal Court的系统、功能和整合的想法和改进导致了一些有趣的变化和改变，而这些变化是我们需要时间进行考虑的。
所以感谢大家的时间和建设性的反馈，我们一定会在不久的将来给出好评。
我们感谢您的理解和耐心。

109829548.review:
Before judging this DLC, people need to take a step back and have a look at what the world has been like for the past year. This DLC in some parts - language, for instance - can be lacklustre. But where the DLC matters, the court and culture overhauls, it blows expectations out of the water.

I played the game nonstop from when Royal Court released (10 to 5pm) up until around half 2am nonstop because I found it so enjoyable. The AI utilising the features in the expansion is very nice to see, especially the new culture mechanics. In one game I saw a Han count form Tibet and create a Han-Tibetan culture. The AI can and will use these mechanics flawlessly.
The royal court itself is a really fun feature and I completely disagree with what others have been saying of it. I don't believe it gets boring at all, I loved creating a long lasting legacy in my court with artifacts and an ever increasing court grandeur. It follows the story of your dynasty and suppliments it in really unique ways that the game is richer for.

So yes, some things aren't as developed as they should be, but this is just a fact of life in the covid-lockdown era world of game development. The parts that are developed fully are done with so much attention and care that it easily hides the parts with less polish.

I cannot recommend this expansion enough.

109829390.review:
Firstly, i can understand everyones frustration with how long the dlc took, and with how much they felt it needed to provide in order to be worth the 30$.

That being said this dlc provides quite a bit in my opinion.

The throne room is a cool cosmetic touch, and provides some cool places to store items you create or plunder from raids ( they brought a form of artifacts back from ck2!). It even allows you to increase different levels of food provided, servants, decorations etc. all of which benefit you by providing positive opinion boost to your courtiers and vassals. My favorite part, however, is that it allows a really cool interaction menu between you and your vassals, or even you and your ruler that i believe was missing. You can now ask your ruler for help against another vassal, or in a war that you're losing. You can have your ruler send men to help increase your control in a country you just conquered etc etc.

Throne room aside, the dlc provides a super interesting language "barrier" if you will now and a huge increase in the cultural significance of the gameplay. Each culture starts with a set language that they speak and if you learn their language (locked at 2 foreign languages to start with more as perks) then they increase opinion of you, which can help you if you decide to make a pairing of your culture and theirs which is in my opinion the best part of the mod. No longer do you have to rule a french people for 500 years and slowly convert them to norse/pagan. You can allow yourself and your people to become one in the same as a Norse-French Culture hybrid (or whatever you decide you want.

This mod adds alot to the game, other then just the throne room that everyone is upset about.

109829356.review:
Not a horrible DLC just overpriced for a series of mechanics that I think were a set of good additions, The culture system is a good continuation of the modular elements similar to religion in the base game. Ultimately I think all the added features should all be part of the base game to enable later changes and prevent a similar state to Europa Universalis IV: where mechanics are ultimately very shallow as mechanics exclusive to certain DLCs cant interact with other DLCs as an individual player may not own others. While things like Bloodlines from CK2 for instance can be very disconnected, its kind of stupid for say EU4 previously having province and ages development being locked behind DLC.

Given the development time and effort its easy to understand why Paradox would see it being worth so much, a 3D element for the court is a large commitment for the developers and a bit different to the usual Paradox grand strategy games. Compared to the Flavor Pack for the Norse I honestly think that 'Expansions' is a poorer way to implement features and a focus should be placed on the packs to enrich regional gameplay for, at least, the major culture groups that are played.

Overall just a very high price and long wait for some admittedly fun mechanics but it could be a spiral of locking away new mechanics behind large paywalls. I would honestly prefer a stream of Flavor Packs for different cultures (might have to group up some less played ones into groups either together or with a big seller that would command the expansion price tag i.e Mongol/Steppe group pack, Ethiopian/East Africa pack, India Pack?). Or maybe Paradox will just make the next expansion amazing, who knows.

109828468.review:
It's good not great, and very overpriced. There's three main features:
1. The royal court. This feature is good but not super engaging. Every now and then you call your royal court and deal with your vassals' issues. And all the court positions are awesome. Unfortunately, I don't really have much more to say since I haven't played much kingdoms in this release. Which leads to another problem: this feature is only useful if you are a kingdom or an empire.
2. Artifacts. This feature is definitely cool and has some great uses. You can buy them, find them, fund their creation, or steal them. Then you can equip them, maintain them, and display them in your court. It's fairly engaging.
3. The new culture system. It's an amazing system, however it simply doesn't get much use. They definitely put a lot of time into it, but how often am I going to diverge or merge my cultures in a playthrough? Maybe two or three times? It simply isn't very engaging. 

So overall all the features are good, but they don't change gameplay enough to warrant a $30 price tag. $20 would be the right amount for this update.

And the game is severely lacking in event diversity. Events tend to repeat over time, to the point that I basically just click through them. The game needs a lot more events, and what would be especially great is regional events, religious, and cultural events. I think those exist right now, but in very small numbers. More events would add a lot more flavor. Just make a $5 dlc with 200 events or something like that.

Lastly, I think the next expansion or dlc should be China.

109827246.review:
This is positive when it could easily be negative. Reason for the positive is that the actual content of the DLC is not, on the whole, *bad*.

What comes with the DLC is the 3d court background for Kings and Emperors (with restrictions), and a way to tailor a culture all for yourself (which costs thousands of prestige). Artifacts are reintroduced, to be displayed at court or 'worn' in a personal inventory. 

And those things are fine. You have a 3d static background for some events instead of a 2d static background. The cultures are interesting in a min/max kind of way and if you ever have a few thousand prestige spare on a ruler then might make for some fun. The events themselves are, generally, well written but have the unfortunate habit of repeating very, very frequently to the point where you wonder if there are only a few of them just constantly cycling through. 

So this is generally fine. This is not bad. Slim pickings in places but clearly a platform for more content from someone some time in the future.

My problem with it is that it's all tailored towards a very specific part of the map and a playstyle which will use those things. And the repetitive nature of events at court (whether as vassal or liege) rapidly leads to me not even noticing the 3d static background in order to scan the text box in the corner of the screen to see if it's something I've already made a decision on several times prior for that particular ruler. It feels pinched. That may be a result of the free update which accompanies this DLC, but it does leave me going back to my old policy of only buying Paradox games and DLC on deep sales.

This review is positive because the content is not *bad*. Whether there's value at any price is really going to be down to how you play and where you play and even with which starting position you play. I don't tick any of those boxes so this isn't something I'd in good conscience say 'go out and buy', but I'd also recommend doing the digging to see whether it's something which interests you and how you play CK3.

109827190.review:
It pains me to give Royal Court a negative review, because I was so excited and hopeful for this DLC.  I couldn't get into Crusader Kings 1 or 2, but CK3 is what finally got me, and I have really loved the game.  I figured upcoming DLC would be up to the same high standards (I liked the Norse flavor pack).

But no.  Royal Court is neither worth the price nor worth the extra long wait.  I'm not even sure why it took so long.  Artifacts are completely underwhelming -- sink some money so you can get a sword that gives you +1 prowess, and then pay for an Antiquarian to slow down its decay, but you eventually need to repair the sword anyways.  I eventually got the Ark of the Covenant and still didn't care.  I stopped trying to get artifacts completely; they just weren't worth the cost and hassle.

Customs are nice, and I'm sure a lot of time was spent on customs, but they just feel like Religion part 2.  I mean, customs give you more rules to live by.  Which is fine and helpful, but nothing mind-blowing.

I was feeling a bit burnt out on CK3, but was so excited for Royal Court to add a fresh element.  But everything added is just kind of blah.  I'm now skeptical of future CK3 DLCs and won't be getting them right away; I'll wait to see the Steam reviews first.
